text:
Quick and easy. I used margarine instead of butter and homogenized milk instead of heavy cream. I did not need to use any thickening agents-the consistency was just right. Just toss with fettucine and serve.

text:
You would not believe how incredible this sauce is!  My husband and I made this sauce (served over fettuccine noodles) for my friend and her husband, as they just had their third child a few days ago and we figured they could use the break from cooking - they went nuts, they loved it so much!  Even their two younger sons (3 and 2) loved this dish.  It literally tastes IDENTICAL to the sauce that they serve at the Olive Garden.  Another good tip is to add a can of drained mushrooms to the sauce - it really tastes great.  I'd give this 6 stars if I could - I will NEVER buy alfredo sauce again!  The next time I might use milk and a little cornstarch instead of the cream (as one previous reviewer suggested) and perhaps reduced fat margarine to save on fat and calories.  Be sure to use fresh shredded parmesan (available in bags in the dairy section), Kraft grated just doesn't do it as well - and the shredded parm melts really well.  ENJOY this incredible dish!  Thank you, Rebecca!  :)

None
text:
Very good flavor in this recipe, but I did add a 2nd clove of garlic. If you just stir the cream into the butter and let it simmer, it will seperate. I gently whisk the cream and butter the entire time it's simmering and whisk while adding the cheese (a little at a time) and it doesn't seperate, even after a day in the fridge. The consistency is a little hard to get smooth, but probably because parmesan is a very hard cheese with a granular texture to begin with, and doesn't melt smoothly. I used a parmesan/asiago blend and it was beautifully smooth after lots of whisking. Also, make sure you use unsalted butter - if you use margarine or lightly salted butter, it's way too salty. I used this recipe to make a white chicken lasagna, which was absolutely delicious, and it held up well in the refrigerator to have leftovers the next day.

text:
Holy Moly! My husband loves alfredo, and he freaked out because this was so good. I made a double recipe, added 1.5 pounds of pan seared chicken breast and poured it over tri-color rotini (it was the only pasta in the house). Unbelievable! It was a little thin at first, but thickened as it cooled. I used genuine Parmesan Reggiano and it melted wonderfully smooth--just be sure to add only a handful at a time. Do not boil, or the sauce will separate.

text:
Bland & throughly uninspired. My husband was none too pleased, and my children were less than enthused which is a far cry from their usual elation with my Italian cooking. I made this for my family yesterday, and recognized the taste right away as being a recipe I've made before though not from this site (copy cat recipes; the book actually). I added 1/8 tsp ground pepper since the flavor was sadly lacking. While I know that I'm am a tough critic having lived for 3 years in Italy this wasn't even passable to my husband who has only visited there with me. This alfredo is fine for someone with a bland palate, but if it's flavor you crave then move on to a recipe more original and authentic.

text:
I made this recipe for my x-mother and father-in-law last weekend. She is an avid vegetarian but will eat seafoods. I made the alfrado using the Gruyere cheese, then in a separate skillet sauted 4 chopped green onions, 1T crushed garlic, and 2T fresh chopped parsley in 2T olive oil, added 1lb cleaned devained shrimp and 1 can lump crab meat over medium heat until shrimp turned pink then folded into the alfrado sauce and served over linguini.

text:
I tried this recipe using 2 different types of parmesan cheese, the shredded kind and the finely grated kind (think Kraft green container).  The shredded was SOOO much better, though both times I used a bit more cream and a bit less cheese.  I used equal amounts and added about a 1/4 cup of cream extra and did about a 1/4 cup less cheese.  We served it with grilled chicken (marinade in Itailian dressing)and grilled red peppers.  YUM!  Thanks for the recipe.  Ths was the best alfredo I've ever had!

text:
Very good basic Alfredo sauce. Remember to keep the sauce at a slow simmer, and never bring to the boil. The high heat will cause the cheese to turn grainy... a slow simmer will keep it smooth and creamy.
Note: A simmer is where the temperature of the liquid is just below the boiling point, or where small bubbles come to the surface and break gently.
You could try different cheeses... why not, or you could substitute the parsley with another herb, such as, Cilantro.

Oh, and I enjoy a bit more garlic... keeps the Vampires away.

text:
Simple ingredients, FANTASTIC FLAVOR! I've made this a few times now and I've learned:  1. definitely use FRESH SHREDDED PARM (instead of the grated green can)- and, just one cup of cheese will suffice  2. use TWO CLOVES MINCED GARLIC  3. HALF&HALF in place of heavy cream  4. CONTINUOS WHISKING! I start whisking when I add the cream to the unsalted butter and I don't stop until I turn my stove off.  ...Thanks for the great recipe, it's a new family fave!

text:
For those who say it is grainy. USE fresh parmesan and grate it yourself and make sure the heat is not too high.

Use heavy cream and REAL butter, not margarine

And for flavor, this is a sauce. The basic sauce is cheese and cream, if you want more flavor, add what you like.

I thought the sauce was perfect. Creamy, I heat on low and simmer slowly to melt slowly. It came out creamy and perfect and easy to prepare.

No problems what so ever. I season with salt and pepper after it is done before I toss or serve it. I like to season accordingly to what I am serving it with.

text:
Tastes amazing.  A funny thing though--after I put the extra sauce in the fridge for later, I took it out the next day and it had congealed to the form of a spreadable cheese.  This was just fine, though, as it microwaved to smooth and creamy.  I found that slicing up some french bread and spreading the leftover alfredo "spread" over it made a delightful cheesy garlic bread after baking.  Regardless of the interesting texture change, the sauce was positively tasty.  Very cheesy.

None
text:
A great basic recipe!  I  don't usually use heavy cream, so I make the roux first with flour, butter and use milk or half and half. I also add a few garlic cloves and have been known to add some steamed broccoli and roasted red peppers.  For those of you who said the texture is not smooth, you need to make sure you buy a block of cheese and grate it yourself or buy it in the cheese department of the grocery not in the Kraft plastic container or any similar, they usually add some kind of anti-caking powder which renders the cheese useless if you want it to melt.   Also, if you add it a bit at a time and stir, you will see better results regarding the cheese melting.

text:
At last, I've adjusted a few things and now it's perfect for us!  Substitute fat-free 1/2 and 1/2 for cream, 1/2 c of shredded parm (from the little plastic tub), LOTS of garlic, pepper to taste, and a block of low fat or Neufchatel cream cheese.  Great taste, not too gluey.  Great with sauteed onion, chicken and frozen (thawed) shrimp.

This sauce is incredible (and not to mention very quick and easy to make)!!  My husband who NEVER says anything is really good actually was the first person to tell me it was really good and then he suggested that I make it again! He even said that he thought it was better than most restaurant's versions! I did however use whole milk instead of the heavy cream and it turned out spectacular.  I also found that if it is too watery then I add a little corn starch to it to make it nice and thick and creamy.  I made a quick chicken scampi to top the pasta and it was a hit with everyone!  Thanks Rebecca, I will never use alfredo from a jar again!

text:
Great recipe as is. If your parmesan cheese doesn't melt, it's because you bought pre-shredded and it has dried and hardened. Freshly shredded has much more moisture content and flavor. And if you really want a treat, use parmagiano-reggiano from Italy. I have also used 1/2 parm and 1/2 asiago for deeper flavors.

I made this tonight with wood grilled zucchini, squash & tomatoes from the garden and added a little bit of fresh rosemary and thyme. Amazing!

text:
This is incredible! Like other reviews say, it really is restaurant quality. I used 2% milk and a tablespoon of corn starch instead of heavy cream because I wanted to cut some calories.  Definitely couldn't tell I tried to cut calories with how rich, creamy and flavorful it was. I used freshly grated Parmesan cheese from the deli section and it melted beautifully... just had to give it enough time. My company was late for dinner and it started to thicken up.  I turned the heat back on, added a bit of milk and stirred it and it was as good as fresh. I made chicken broccoli alfredo over Asian stir-fry rice noodles to keep it gluten free for my 6-year-old who has gluten sensitivity. Perfect meal with a side of veggies and garlic bread. What's also great is that it doesn't take long to make!  Cubing the chicken was the most time consuming part.

text:
I don't usually review recipes, but I just HAD to review this one. As a devoted customer of Olive Garden, I was skeptical when I made this... so many people had reviewed it, saying that it was as good as Olive Garden. Now I love that stuff--I get alfredo dipping sauce for the breadsticks, & I get fettucine alfredo as my meal! But honestly, this alfredo is just as good, or even better. I made it for my mother, & she liked it so much that she begged me to make another batch of it for her the very same day! It truly is a wonderful recipe, & I will be using it a lot. One note: when making it, make sure that you stir in the cheese slowly, and also make sure that you whisk it while you do so. Basically, after you add the cream and it begins to simmer, you will need to whisk it every few seconds for the rest of the time it is cooking. Otherwise, it will separate. It is a very good, easy recipe-- a real treat for busy women! :)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Gourmet at home!! I can't believe I made this!! Fantastic recipe. I used minced garlic, and only 1 1/4 cup shredded parm (because it was easier to grab a bag and it was pre measured. It still came out very creamy! And super FAST!! Excellent plain with pasta - I added shrimp and scallops and felt like I was at the Olive Garden! I plan to have a "make your own" dinner with family over and offer chicken, shrimp or scalops to go on linguine and this alfredo!

Tip I found for knowing when the parm is melted enough in the original cook time - lift the whisk out of the pan every minute or so and when it is no longer stringy it is fully incorporated. That's when it's the most creamy! 

Sauce will separate upon reheat but if you reheat it on its own (instead of on the pasta) you can whisk it back into a cream. On the pasta you get clumps and oils, but the flavor remains! I reheated mine on low heat and stirred with a whisk until it came back together and it was just like the first day! DEE-LISH!!

text:
I had an idea of the kind of dish I wanted to fix, so this is what I did.  I cut up 2 chicken breasts into chunks and sauteed them until done in a pan.  I added steamed broccoli and 2 sliced green onions to the chicken and then poured this Alfredo sauce over it.  I doubled the sauce.  I didn't use as much parmeasan, but I did thicken the sauce slightly with a little flour and water.  It was DELICIOUS and there was hardly any left overs.  I also didn't use the heavy cream, but I used half and half instead.  I've finally found the Chicken and Broccoli Alfredo I've been looking for and it's as good as anything you'll ever get in a restaurant.  Thanks for the inspiration.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Quick, easy, flavorful, what's not too like? Some people have mentioned a few problems with this recipe, cheese not melting, cheese separating, too thick, and too thin. Here's a few fixes. Cheese not melting, try adding the cheese in 3-4 increments while whisking (not string). Cheese separating, you're cooking at too high a temp, cook no higher than low/med. Too thick, add a little of the pasta water. Too thin? The starch will thicken it when you add the pasta to it (remember this is not a sauce you ladle on like red sauce). Happy cooking :)

text:
Very yummy, easy-to-make alfredo sauce. Note that the balance of cheese and cream is delicate - too much cream and the sauce is runny, too much cheese and the sauce is very thick. I usually don't measure exactly, but if I put in too much cheese, I balance it out with more cream.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A GREAT base recipe! Here's some things I've tried:
-more garlic, and add it right away with the butter so you really infuse that flavor
-onions, chives, and/or shallots
-peppers (you could even get crazy an add some spice!)
-salt, sea salt, seasoning salt, etc.
-black or white pepper
-paprika
-Italian blend seasonings
-a couple of different cheeses
-if you're eating it with shrimp, add a seafood seasoning blend.  Steak, a steak blend.  Chicken...you get the idea.
-whatever tastes good!
-and finally, a little flour to help thicken it up more.

Also, you can totally skip the parm and exchange it for cheddar and/or pepper jack and - ta da! - nacho cheese sauce! 

Remember: recipes are just GUIDELINES and meant to explore and have fun with! (And I learned that while in the USA!) ;)

Simply amazing! I had an inexplicable craving for fettuccine alfredo. I usually cook healthy, but sometimes you just have to give into those cravings. I doubled the garlic and like another reviewer suggested, whisked the entire 5 minutes of simmering to prevent the sauce from separating. We topped this off with "Marinated Grilled Chicken II" from this site and a salad and it was a wonderful meal!

text:
This is a GREAT recipe.  If it is too salty you used SALTED butter, use unsalted.  The trick to successfully making any alfrado is SLOWLY adding the ingredients. First slighly warming the milk in the microwave and SLOWLY adding teh milk so it absorbs and is combined before added me.  Then add the cheese a teaspoon at a time. IF you add it too quickly it will cling together... Also, adding a little of your pasta water wil thicken it up from the strach and give it an authentic taste. I add Sundried tomatoes and Pinenuts. ITs a great recipe but it

Wonderful! My husband is very picky and he loved this sauce! Also, my mother-in-law was over for dinner when I made this and raved about it! She even asked for the leftovers for lunch the next day! text:
I am surprised to read that some reviewers found the sauce too runny.  I have made this sauce 3 times in the past couple of weeks (it's THAT good!!) and all 3 times, I had to add more cream after whisking in the cheese because it was just too THICK!  I may experiment with using less cheese in the future, but either way, this recipe is AMAZINGLY delicious!  **UPDATE** I tried making this thinner by adding less cheese, but it was not flavorful enough.  I will just continue to add a little cream as needed after whisking in the cheese.  I also add black pepper.

text:
I've tried this recipe with heavy cream, light cream, milk, and various Parmesan cheeses. I prefer the light cream with a nutty, hand grated Parmesan. My experience with Kraft and other pre-grated Parmesans have made the sauce less flavorful and the texture gloopy.

Display Name:
Yoshiyum

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this sauce about 5 times now, and its WONDERFUL. The first time I made it I thought it didnt quite have enough spice to it (I grew up in a garlic type family) so I added 4 cloves of garlic instead of 1, and I still do. As well, the sauce itself when made directly from the recipe may be too thick to serve right away...after I mix the Parmesan in with the butter and cream and let it melt, I add a little milk and stir, and continue to add milk until the consistancy is better...it doesnt take away from the flavor and makes this dish PERFECT. If that doesnt jive you, you could try adding a little less parmesan and add the left over to the top of your pasta dish when its done. 

Also, I got requests to instead add the parsley as a garnish on top, instead of inside the meal itself, I do that as well.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I gave it 5 stars but I made a few changes out of necessity. First, I only had half and half and about 3/4 cup of parmesan cheese. I accidentally added the garlic WITH the cream, but it tasted great. I brought it almost to a boil and stirred constantly for about 5 minutes.  Also, before I added the cheese, I beat an egg yolk and tempered it by adding a couple of tablespoons of the hot cream mixture to the yolk while stirring it. (The egg yolk was part of another alfredo recipe I got from this site. It makes the sauce silky.). I then whisked it into the cream and added the cheese. I just realized that I forgot the parsley, lol!  It was SO good; my kids loved it. I used Rotini which was great because the sauce stuck to it really well. I would have used a little more cheese if I'd had it, but probably not all 1.5 cups. Thanks, Rebecca!

userID:
8865635
Display Name:
NoRainOnMyParade
isPro:
False

1

0
madeRecipesCount:
12
favoritesCount:
78
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3090571.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Parmesean melts perfectly fine if you use fresh cheese that you grate yourself.  The pre-shredded cheese has preservatives and other additives which WILL change the viscosity and texture of the sauce.

This sauce is really good AS IS if you FOLLOW the directions.  DO NOT let it BOIL, as that will make your cheese GRITTY. DO stir pretty much continuously after adding the cheese, and keep the heat no higher than a simmer (simmering is when the sauce may have some small bubbles that gently rise and pop, but generally there is little to no bubbling).  DO use a whisk. 

I like to add a little romano cheese in addition to the parmesean for a subtle shift in flavor, and because I LOVE garlic, I use at least two cloves.  I rarely have fresh parsley but substitute dried and also like to add a pinch of nutmeg and sometimes a TINY bit of sauteed freshly minced onion.

While visiting family for Christmas, we made an AWESOME alfredo pasta dish for Ronald McDonald house (we volunteered to prepare dinner the day after Christmas). I'll for sure make this again - and often! :-)

text:
This sauce was very good overall, but I did run into a problem with the cheese melting in smoothly. I used shredded and mixed asiago, romano and parmesean cheeses. I added musherooms to this recipe by request and it was a yummy addition. If you're making it with the same cheeses, allow about 30 munutes of time to get it successfully mixed in. I cannot afford some of the other cheeses mentioned by others that have reviewed as alternates for an easy-melting cheese.

text:
Great recipe when you're looking for quick dinner ideas! I didn't have heavy cream, but I found an equivalent (1/3 c butter, 3/4 milk, 1 tbsp flour). Used 1 clove elephant garlic (which is about 2-3 cloves of regular garlic) and 3/4 c parmigiana. Much more cheese than that seemed to be too much. It came out thick, creamy and the SO loved it to pieces.

Would work great with a stronger cheese like Gruyere or even Gorgonzola if you're adventurous.

I like that this recipe is easy, and it did taste good, but I was not a fan of the consistency.  The parmesan did not melt well and left kind of a grainy consistency.  I like my sauce much smoother than this came out. I also added milk as this came out super thick after I added the cheese.  I prefer the Quick and Easy Alfredo recipe from this website, but taste-wise after tweaking, this is a close second. I will probably make again if short on time.

text:
I will make it again!  I used Best Life Margarine instead of butter, 2% Milk instead of heavy cream and 2 cloves of garlic instead of one.  I see some reviewers mentioned adding corn starch if they use milk the next time they make it.  There is NO NEED to add corn starch, just cook it a little longer before and after the addition of the cheese while stirring constantly with a whisk.  That's what I did and it turned out beautifully.

As mentioned by a couple of reviewers, I used GRATED cheese and thought the texture was a bit grainy (and no, I didn't break my sauce!).  As a couple other reviewers mentioned, I think I will use 1 cup Gruy√®re and 1/2 cup of a shredded Parm instead.  I am not a huge fan of the Olive Garden Alfredo, it's a bit too salty for my taste, so I feel using the Gruy√®re will tame the salt a bit.  (Then I can add some bacon or pancetta too!).  Enjoy!  This is a winner sauce.  Thank you to it's author!

userID:
4402046
Display Name:
Jaym
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

1
favoritesCount:
9
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/354517.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As a newbie to cooking I'm hesitant to rate a recipe, but I have eaten more than my share of Alfredo at dozens of restaurants.  This recipe is quite possible the best I have had.  I have modified it some because I don't like garlic or parsley.  The first time I made it I used a little garlic salt in place of garlic.  The results were outstanding!  But it still had the garlic taste that I do not care for.  Another time I left it out all together.  The recipe seemed lacking.   Last night I added sun dried tomatoes.  I have never dried tomatoes before, it took almost 20 hours in the oven!  Next time I'll just buy some, I can't even imagine what my electric bill will be.  My wife and I don't like biting in to chunks of sun dried tomato, so I ground it almost to a paste in a food processor.    With that, I have the best Alfredo I have ever had.  It might be important to mention that I made the pasta fresh, and added charbroiled chicken.  So my modified recipe: 1/4 cup butter 1 cup heavy cream 1/4 cup (rough estimate) ground up sun dried tomatoes. 1 1/2 cups freshly grated parmesan cheese.  The directions are the same, I added the chicken and tomatoes after the cheese was mixed in.  ~Jay

5

text:
Very good alfredo sauce, and easy too! I doubled the recipe and had to use light cream because I had a pint I needed to use before it spoiled. I used a bit less cheese though, and this sauce still turned out super thick. I used freshly grated parmesan which is very important, do not use the grated cheese that comes in the container. My boyfriend said this tasted just like Olive Garden's sauce which he loves. I used Farfalle pasta (bowties) and topped with Quorn brand vegetarian chicken cutlets. This was an excellent meal. I will use this recipe again for sure. We really like the addition of the garlic also. Thanks for sharing :)

text:
I have reviewed  quite a few alfredo recipes here with good ratings, HOWEVER I do know that this is a true restaurant style alfredo sauce, and I don't mean the ol' olive garden close to the mall.. I mean a quality Italian restaurant. to make alfredo, most chefs simply melt butter, add cream, maybe garlic, toss in real Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese, toss in fresh pasta & serve... the cheese melts as it sits in the hot pasta.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
All together this was too much.  The cream should have been half and half, and cut in half and mixed with an equal part of chicken broth.  That not only adds to the flavor, but will cut down on that buttery fatty taste in your mouth afterwards.  Also, cut the butter in half and add flour to make a roux.  Then add another soft dairy product, cream cheese, preferably neufchatel, perhaps a half of a block.  Add that to the roux, then the garlic, then the liquid, then the parsley, only don't add so much.  Parsley is an herb that pulls together flavors, not one that stars on its own.  That's why is the most popular GARNISH, not the most popular spice, salt, which isn't in this recipe, which was okay by me.

Amazing.. This recipe has become my go to whenever I want a delicious alfredo sauce.  This recipe is quick, easy and amazingly tasty.  Whenever I'm in a hurry I'll substitute an Italian Cheese Blend for the Parmesan because it usually melts more easily. Overall though, this is a wonderful recipe and the flavor is even better than some restaurant recipes.

Excellent alfredo sauce! If you have ever heard of "Blackened Chicken Alfredo" from TGI FRidays, I tried to replicate it today using this as the sauce. Upon finding a blackened chicken recipe, I made the noodles and this sauce (the minced garlic and a little more of it is a MUST). I poured this sauce over the noodles, spinkled some diced pimentos and minced green onions and placed the blackened chicken on top. WOW! Not only did it look gourmet but tasted just as good. Its only too bad this recipe is SOO unhealthy for you but caution was thrown to the wind today and my boyfriend and I ate this lunch. Every bite was worth it. Thanks Rebecca for the great alfredo sauce!

text:
Immediately after beginning this recipe I had thought that I made a grave mistake and had bit off much more than I could chew. However after mildly shredding my thumb along with the Parmesan and ultimately deciding "chopped" was close enough to "shredded", I made it through and decided this was definitely worth the minor blood loss. I also added broccoli, spinach, and chicken to the sauce as well as using part gruyere cheese and put it over a 3-cheese ravioli. Note: if you bleed on the cheese do not use that cheese, dispose of it and plan ahead by purchasing a bit extra cheese.

text:
This is my standard alfredo recipe. In order to get good results you ABSOLUTELY MUST use fresh grated cheese! Preshredded packaged cheese and the stuff in the green can have added ingredients that make the sauce clump and taste gritty. This is a good basic method for any cheese sauce. You can change up the cheese with cheddar and pour over macaroni, add emmental and gruyere and enjoy a swanky fondu. In every instance, you MUST use freshly grated cheese.

It was easy and turned out great after I added the extra garlic. I served it on fetticine. With a ceasar salad and garlic bread, it was like eating at a restaurant. :)

I made Chicken Alfredo with this sauce and it was a big hit. The sauce was very thick so I added an additional 1/2 cup of heavy cream and it turned out velvety smooth. I also added the Parmesan in half cups increments so that it would melt evenly. The jarred sauces are so full of preservatives and I'd rather do without them. After finding this recipe there's no need to resort to jarred Alfredo sauce again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this last night and it was excellent with this substitution: one cup of grated mixed Romano/Parmesan (Kraft) and a half a cup of higher quality grated Pecorino Romano cheese that I brought back from Italy. You could get a similar quality of cheese from any good deli in the States.  Romano cheese is sharper and much more flavorful than Parmesan. The sauce was excellent just with that substitution, but then I also added some morel mushrooms and topped with cooked crumbled bacon (didn't have prosciutto - ham would have worked well, too) and it was incredible. The quality of the cheese you add is the key to this recipe.

text:
I just tried this recipe, but with a few changes. First of all, its bad idea to simmer the sauce then add the parmesan at the end because it wont have enough time to melt, so I added everything in one go: garlic, parmesan, parsley at the very beginning before simmering the sauce then I simmered it all together. Came out great! Additionally, I added cooked chicken breast to make it a chicken alfredo sauce next to some pasta.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/567741.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a good start.  I knew from reading the recipe that it didn't have enough garlic for my family so I chose to use 3-cloves.  That's a personal preference so I did not ding the recipe for that.  However, even using the heavy cream the sauce did come out very thin.  I mixed a little (1 heaping teaspoon) of corn starch to a little water and added it the sauce.  It only took a minute or so at a slow simmer for the sauce to thicken right up.  I also added a teaspoon of black pepper (again personal preference).  Since you can not allow a cream sauce to boil, I also think it best to add the garlic when melting the butter and allow it to saut√© for 2 or 3 minutes.

text:
This is restaurant quality alfredo and a lot easier than some recipes I've used with flour.  Instead of using the whole cup of heavy cream, I used 3/4 cup cream & 1/4 skim milk to make it slightly more healthy. It wasn't as thick as some I've made in the past, but it wasn't watery. Don't buy alfredo in a jar, this is easy and delicious!

text:
Can I just say...wow!  Followed recipe exactly (except when I read one clove of garlic...i use 4...always)...except I was looking for spinach alfredo..so prior to making the sauce as described, I heated olive oil, garlic, crushed red pepper then sauteed spinach in that mixture..set aside. Then, in same pan followed recipe to the letter..added my spinach as the last step...so good..best alfredo I have ever had..ty so much for sharing. After reading some of the reviews...especially those that said this was bland...I feel like I must note that Alfredo is a cheese sauce...and is definitely dependent on the cheese one chooses to use..I would imagine the original poster, as I, used a good cheese as a base which is why there was no need for "extras" to make it taste good. :)

text:
I made this recipie as described with one minor change. I simmer the garlic in the butter for a few minutes before adding the cream. This brings out the oil-soluble flavors and aroma of the garlic, infusing them into the butter. Aside from that I followed this recipe to the letter and it comes out perfectly!

text:
This is a good basic recipe - only thing missing are the seasonings:  a dash of salt, pepper (maybe 2 dashes) and nutmeg about 1/4 tsp.  Don't add the cheese too early or it gets stringy but melt the butter and warm the milk add the pasta and then just as you are ready to take it off the heat add your cheese, salt/pepper/nutmeg.  Grate fresh parmesan cheese on top just before serving.  Our family favourite is to add chunks of ham.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
It is delicious and riddiculously easy!!! I didn't have all ingredients on hand so i made do. I swapped out butter with margarine and simmered garlic in butter before adding the cream. I used 1 tblsp of crushed garlic you buy in a jar. Didn't have any cream so I substituted 1 cup of cold milk with 3tsp of cornstarch wisked in, for thickening. make sure the milk is cold and whisk in until there are no more lumps. added that to the butter and garlic , whisking on a low simmer until it thickened to a consistency that I liked. All I had was whole milk mozzarella so I shredded a cup and added 1/3 cup of kraft parmesan tha comes in the green bottle. whisked it in slowly a little at a time till it was all melted, never bringing to a boil , just a low simmer. It was ridiculousy good!  My husband is one of those that never says its good. He loved it! 
And had seconds and thirds. Thanks for posting this. will make more often with different kinds of cheeses.

I give this 4 stars. This recipe is the perfect base. I cut the fat in half and did not use heavy cream. I had to use a little more than the 1 c. to thin out the sauce and make it creamier. I followed other reviews and used half and half instead. The only thing this recipe is missing is the seasoning. I added salt and pepper and the flavor was perfect. I also used an Italian blend cheese instead of fresh parmesean or romano. It tasted better than any restaurant. I am happy I found this recipe.

text:
I followed this recipe several times and love it.  After a while, I began to experiment.  I put in more garlic, and combined Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese with parmesan (1 cup and 1/2 cup, respectively).  It makes it much creamier and with a little more bite.  A tip to reheat - warm slowly and add in extra cream to keep it's consistency, or else the cheese and butter separate.

text:
I thought this was pretty good over stuffed crab ravioli. However, I did make a few changes. I wanted to try and duplicate the sauce served at Carrabas over their lobster ravioli. I think I came close. I first sauteed some onion and pretty much followed the directions until after adding the cream and letting it cook.  I then added 1/4 can of petite canned tomatoes and a teaspoon of minced garlic. I let that cook for another 4-5 min then added the parsley and served immediately. Will def try again!

text:
I don't think I would change anything about this recipe and left it completely as is, other than adding about half a tsp of ground white pepper. The sauce was rich and creamy and the perfect consistency as it began to cool. I would say that if you prefer a slightly less rich taste, you may want to add a little less cheese.. We used 100% natural Parmigiano-Reggiano (Parmesan) and it was terrific. Also, I'd like to mirror what some other reviewers have written - that I never knew Alfredo could be this fast and easy and I will make it much more frequently now that I know! Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I'm giving this 4 stars only b/c I changed it a bit. Otherwise, it was great. I used 2 small garlic cloves and I sauteed them in the melted butter for a couple minutes before adding half and half. I also added a little freshly ground pepper and a sprinkle of  nutmeg. I used freshly grated parm from my grocery deli. I stopped at 1 cup; 1 1/2 would have been WAY too much. I wish I had stopped at 1/2 cup b/c the sauce was too thick for my taste. I tossed the sauce with some sauteed broccoli and cooked chicken before adding it to my noodles. It's a pretty good sauce, but I'll decrease the parm next time.

country:
None
text:
As written: just 4 stars.  Here's why....made exactly as written, the end result was very thick and needed pepper.  So the changes I made were pretty simple: I whisked in more cream, probably another 1/3 cup in addition to what the recipe called for.  I added it in small amounts until the consistency was perfect.  I also added several cranks of freshly ground black pepper (because to me, alfredo isn't alfredo without black pepper) and an extra clove of garlic.  With my minor revisions, this sauce is absolutely outstanding and definitely a keeper.  I served it tossed with shrimp and capellini.  Just be sure you're not on a diet the night you make this for dinner.  ;)

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Following the advice of others here, I doubled the recipe to be sure I had enough.  In the process, I used a can of evaporated milk (and a little 2% milk when that didn't quite make 2 cups), and tossed in a tablespoon of flour for thickness.  I minced 3 garlic cloves for the doubled recipe.  I had 2 bags of 1.5 cups of the Parmesan, but left about a third of the 2nd bag.  The constant whisking/stirring was great, but even still, my sauce caught a little at the bottom when I accidentally left it for too long and didn't watch the heat.  No biggie, though... there was no burn smell or taste, and the scraped up parts from the bottom gave my sauce some character.  :)  Lastly, I added a dash of chili powder, some white pepper, some black pepper, and two sprinkles of dried parsely.  I poured it all over whole wheat shells, along with shrimp and broccoli I had sauteed with olive oil, more garlic, and other seasonings in a separate pan.  De-lish!  Will definitely use this again.

text:
Wonderfully easy alfredo sauce! I didn't know what to expect as the ingredients were pretty basic but it turned out wonderful! I have always been a little IF-ie of making a good alfredo as I thought it would be too rich... too salty... too bland. I am definitely a beginner when it comes to cooking and I will definately be making this one again.  I used fat free half and half to cut the heaviness (and calories!) and sauteed the garlic in the butter before adding the cream. I added creamed spinich and roasted tomatoes and folded them in at the end and omitted the parsley as I didn't want to waste the rest of the bushel. I topped farafelle pasta with grilled chicken strips and the awesome alfredo. Only problem I had was getting the shredded parmesan cheese to melt completely. Maybe next time I will try gruyere. Thanks for the recipe- this ones a keeper!!

userID:
2422771
Display Name:
elin.jean
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
24
favoritesCount:
227
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Alfredo sauce was always something I thought I should like but never did until this recipe. I considered adding extra garlic, but found one medium or large clove of garlic gave plenty of flavor. I also use a dash of white pepper, and a little bit of dried parsley in place of fresh (I find fresh parsley to be bitter). Perfect!  The first time I made it I used block parmesan that I shredded myself with a rotary grater, and it melted beautifully. I also tried it with "fresh" grated parmesan (the powdery kind, but from the deli case), and it didn't turn out as well -- the texture remained gritty.  Definitely whisk the butter and cream together, and stir occasionally with the whisk while simmering to avoid separating, but you shouldn't need to whisk the whole time.   The sauce reheats well by itself with some vigorous stirring with a whisk or fork, but doesn't reheat very well if it's already on the pasta. So if you think you'll have leftovers, only toss as much pasta and sauce together as you're going to eat right away.

text:
Very good recipe!  I don't make this too often, only because of the fat content, but it is VERY good.  I don't use parsley, and sometimes use romano cheese instead of parm; there's not much of a difference.  You just have to remember to continuously wisk and add the cheese a little at a time.  The only problem I have is that the leftovers always separate when reheating; don't know if that is something that is preventable.  Great recipe though; thank you!

text:
I have tried several different alfredo sauce recipes and I also found that parmesan cheese doesn't melt very well...my sauce always seemed to come out grainy...I took your and some other readers' advice about using Gruyere cheese...I shredded it fresh...and I have never gotten a sauce as smooth and creamy! I also added an egg yolk and used garlic salt instead of fresh garlic, and also added some black pepper (based on some other alfredo recipes I've seen). The sauce was perfect!!!! Thanks for the suggestion on the Gruyere cheese! It's definitely the way to go!!!!

text:
I was looking for this recipe because I'd been using almost the exact same recipe that someone sent me calling it an Olive Garden copycat.  The only difference was this recipe called for TWICE the amount of parmesan!  I've been wanting to try using fresh garlic for awhile so I requested my mom buy some when she shopped for groceries.  She also picked up a garlic press and I went to town.  We have a large family of ten children so I quadrupled this.  After reading some reviews I tried adding an extra clove of garlic and did not put the full amount of parmesan because we didn't have enough.  Oh my gosh this stuff is incredible!!  I think the fresh garlic is what kicks it over the edge.  Before it was just kind of blah but this, oh this is great!!  Will make again and again!!!

text:
This sauce was wonderful!  I made this on a Friday during Lent when I needed a meatless dish.  I only made a couple of changes to it.  I made it just as stated in the recipe and thought it was a little too thick.  I thinned it out a bit by using a little milk.  I also wanted a little more color so I soaked 1/4 cup of chopped sun-dried tomatoes in some chicken broth and added them with the parsley.  Not only was the dish more colorful, the tomatoes made it more flavorful.  I poured it over some whole wheat penne rigate pasta and served it bread and salad.  YUM!

text:
I would give this 5 stars however I found it bland...I always add sherry, I find it amusing when others reviewing say when they have kids they don't add alcohol, THE ALCOHOL IS COOKED OFF! All that's left is the flavor, your kids nor you will get drunk, I promise. Also I like to fine grind fresh nutmeg before serving, just a bit seems to really bring in a lot of flavor,(it's fine to use the pre-powered if that's all you have). Seriously I don't get all that parsley, Italian has way more flavor, but not a whole lot from the "regular"...maybe color...for me it's always about taste, presentation...not ineatable garnish!Do add cut up grilled chicken breast; shrimp; seafood; grilled veggies; have fun with recipes and tweak them to suit your taste, and your family. Taste as you go along, try a smaller amount just for you before you make it for company. The main ingredient you need is LOVE!

Display Name:
Susan Parran

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2449113.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a nice sauce for a basic meal of homemade spinach fettucine and pork medalions simmered in a tomato-apricot and white wine reduction. I suggest that anyone having trouble with the strong flavor of the Parmesan cheese look specifically for COW's milk Parmesan, which is not as tangy as sheep's milk parm. Also, stay away from any Parmesan cheese that states a long aging process on its label. The rennet in the cheese may go "off," and the longer the cheese sits, the  more likely it is that you get that intense "tang" of the increased microbials - akin to the process for bleu-veined (moldy-looking) cheeses. With this recipe, I added cumin and just the smallest dash (seriously, like less than 1/8 tsp.) of fresh grated nutmeg. I was also liberal with pepper because I like it that way.

text:
I read alot of reviews about this before I made it. I used unsalted butter, and I used the parmesian and romano cheese blend. I have a "Gizmo" which comes with a wire whisk attatchment and I used it when I added my cheese at 1/4 cup at a time. It made it so smooth and it never got gritty due to the constant whisking. So if you have one I highly recommend it. At the end I folded in some fresh lump crab meat and served it over penne pasta, it was awesome and it really did taste alot like the Olive Garden, even my family said so without me saying anything about it. This was a very easy dinner that was a huge hit.

Made this for dinner tonight.. it was okay. A little bit to salty for my taste. It was smooth and not grainy at all as others have stated. Not even sure how grainy is possible with the ingredients listed?? Are you sure your parlsey was washed thoroughly? I always find a ton of sand at the bottom of my bowl that i use to wash my parlsey in. Fill up a big bowl full of water and wash parlsey thouroughly that might be the problem. I had a hard cheese grater, that alows me to grate very finely. It melted in seconds. It was very easy to make.

This is such a great sauce. I read a few reviews and when I went shopping bought both Romano and Parmesean cheese. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My daughter had to have this for her 18th birthday. This is the 3rd time I have made this sauce and I will never buy store bought again. It always turns out smooth for me. The secret is to get the butter and cream hot enough and slowly add the cheese, while whisking away like crazy. I let the parmasean sit out a little while before using, so it's not cold. I thin it out a little by adding 1/4c or so extra milk or cream. Don't leave out the fresh crushed garlic clove, that makes it! We add 2 Tbs of juliened sun dried tomatoes (in oil) and cooked chicken after the sauce is smooth.

I thought this recipe was great! I used half Gruyere/half Parmesan. I added them slowly and stirred frequently and the cheese seemed to melt just fine, although there was some texture, but it wasn't bad at all! I also added salt and pepper, a few pinches of nutmeg, and a little more garlic like some other people suggested. It had a great flavor! I think the Gruyere definitely helped some of the texture problems others were experiencing, so try it!

text:
Every bit as good as Olive Garden!  Make sure you use this with raw pasta found in the refrigerated section of the grocery store.  If you like more garlic, I use an entire bulb.  Simmer peeled garlic in 1/4 cup butter for 20 minutes, mix in 1 Tbsp flour, add 1/4 cup milk, cook 2 more minutes, then strain into alfredo sauce.

text:
I have made this recipe over 10 times and it's a HUGE hit; for dinner, as an appetizer, you name it! Found that the sauce will get thicker the longer you let it simmer, and not to use already shredded parmesan. (It doesn't melt well at all!) Grate it yourself; it's worth the pain!

Display Name:
SHAWNALTON

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe, however, I varied a bit from it and wanted a bit richer sauce so I used a whole pint of heavy cream, 1/2 cup butter and only 3/4 cup grated Parmesan cheese.  I know that Parmesan is not the the easiest cheese to melt in sauces and was very skeptical about using fresh so I used what I had and that was the big container that you can get at Costco Wholesale. The brand is Messana and I tell you , it was perfect!!!!  It wasn't too rich and that cheese blended very well in the sauce.  I think it really does make a difference in the cheese you use.  I had used fresh not too long ago and it globbed up on me and I was really disappointed.  I recommend the type I used if you have a Costco.  I also added a couple of tablespoons of cream cheese and WOW, very good.  Thanks for the recipe!

This is a pretty standard Alfredo recipe and is solid gold.. 
It is an easy sauce to break by overheating or not keeping whisked so .. be warned..
Stick with the "name brand" Parmesan or get fresh parmesan reggiano..   I have not found an "off" brand of pre-grated parm that was worth a darn (too much like sawdust)  Hence perhaps if you use cheap cheese, you get "bland" flavor?

text:
I read some of the comments bellow, and I was wondering why my experience was soooo different than the negative ones.
Until one day I followed the recipe to the comma, and got the cheese-ball result.  I would therefore recommend to respect the butter and heavy-cream ration (for a thick and flavorful result) and simply reduce the Parmesan to half of what the recipe suggests. Specially if your grating your Parmesan super thin, or buy the powder type; you'll be adding more Parmesan than required. So either weight it, or go with your guts. Less is more sometimes.

Display Name:
Connie Horton Meredith
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2403351.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It is an awesome, EASY, rich creamy base Alfredo sauce. It's what you do with it that either makes it incredible or a boring edible.
You can see in the recipe that there isn't even salt or pepper. Adding some fresh ground pepper and a dash of salt to the sauce is kind of a no brainer. I agree with the others that said shredded cheese was far better than the Kraft parm. 
I sauteed mushrooms and onion in some butter and garlic. I boiled some fresh spinach and feta ravioli, drained it and threw it into the pan with the mushrooms and onion. I sauteed that for a few minutes  before adding the sauce. 
It was beautiful when plated, the smell alone intoxicating and the taste definitely 5 stars and had the ability to impress!
Use the sauce as your base and use your brain for some inspiration!

userID:
4309111
Display Name:
Dwight
isPro:
False
followersCount:
6
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
82
favoritesCount:
206
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I gave this a 5 star because it's the easiest and best basic Alfredo Sauce recipe I've found.  I did make some changes though after reading all the other recipes and some reviews of this one.  I used half the butter and the same amount of extra virgin olive oil.  I added the garlic to the oil before the cream.  The hot oil pulls all the flavor out of the garlic.  Don't brown it though.  I added a dash of white pepper.  I used a combination of Italian cheeses, Parmesan, Romano, Asaigo, and Provolone.  For Heaven's sake, DON'T use that powdered Parmesan.  It has Cellulose and preservatives in it that make it not cream as well.  Slivers of fresh Basil make a good garnish.

Delicious.  I made some changes just based on what I had.  I only had 3/4 cup of heavy cream so I used milk for the last 1/4 cup.  I had just over a cup of freshly grated Parmesan, so I added shredded mozzarella for the rest of the cheese.  Added a second clove of garlic and a little garlic pepper.  Per other reviewers I whisked gently the entire time as soon as I added the cheese and had no separation or grittiness issues.  I can't speak to leftovers because it all got eaten.  Served with sliced sausage over fettuccini and not only was it tasty, but it was one of the easier meals I make.

text:
Great recipe! It's super easy to make and easy to convert into another sauce. When I make it I only use half then save the other for the next night. I will char a red pepper on the grill with a little olive oil then warm up the leftover alfedo. Take out the seeds of the pepper and quarter it and place it in a food processor and add the warm Alfredo. Serve it over grilled chicken breast or mozzarella stuffed meatloaf. It's great and my son loves it!

text:
I used half shredded Romano, half  shredded Parmesan. My only other changes: I put my crushed garlic in after the butter had melted and let it sizzle slightly for a few seconds, then added the cream. It's also always been my custom to put a pinch of fresh grated nutmeg in Alfredo, so I did that as well...I loved this recipe, because other Alfredo recipes I've tried have had egg. You have to be so super careful to add the egg so it won't cook or curdle. No worries regarding that here....This is a lovely sauce! Alfredo is not supposed to pack a big punch! It's supposed to be delicate, cheesy, and subtle! This lived up to my expectations of a good Alfredo, and it was so EASY!

text:
I've made this many times. One time I made plans to make this for my Aunt and I. By the night of the dinner she invited her neighbors and another friend of hers. No pressure. 
  I used a recipe for garlic bread I found in my magic bullet cookbook and balsamic strawberries for dessert from here also.  I followed the recipe exactly except I like more garlic and I use already crushed from a jar. I pre-measure everything first and put on standby.  With the cream you don't want to take the time to measure something mid boil and risk burning the cream. 
  Timing was perfect and everything finished in prefect sequence. I got great reviews including "better than any restaurant". My Aunt had broken out the fine china and the table looked like a fancy restaurant.  Best meal ever.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Quick and easy Alfredo Sauce.  Yes, it's high in fat, but that's Alfredo sauce ...or at least the kind of Alfredo we wanted.  I used a wedge of parmesan and grated it just before using, adding a three-finger pinch to the pot at a time, stirring until melted, and then adding another pinch until all the cheese was incorporated.  Of course it separates when you heat it up again, so don't plan to have leftovers.  They taste fine, but you're reminded of just how much fat is in there when it separates on the reheat.  I probably used more garlic than the recipe calls for, but I do that in just about everything I cook.  Disclaimer: I've never lived in Italy, never gone to culinary school, and didn't expect this recipe to not present a very real risk to my coronary arteries.  Thank you for sharing this recipe.

This is my first time making any sauce and it would not be my last! I made it exact and it turned out fantastic!! I cannot believe I have been buying store bought Alfredo sauce all these year. lol I added shrimp to mine to make shrimp alfredo. text:
This is the first time I've ever made anything from a recipe off the internet. I've recently, at 45, decided to learn to really cook - not just heat things up or saut√© veggies and boil pasta. The first time I messed up. I used salted butter against the advice of many here who recommended using unsalted butter, and I used shredded parmesan in stead of grated. It was waaaaaaaay to rich and the parmesan didn't melt thoroughly. The second time, I used UNSALTED butter and GRATED parmesan, but I still used 2 cloves of garlic instead of 1. IT IS DELICIOUS!!!!

Absolutely amazing and much better than any store bought Alfredo Sauce. If you make this REMEMBER! GRATED not SHREDDED Parmesan and UNSALTED not SALTED Butter.

I saved the remainder and put it in the fridge. It formed into a solid paste when I removed it from the fridge just now. I'm not sure if that is supposed to happen, but it tasted delicious as leftovers! I just saut√©ed some mushrooms and spinach in olive oil in a large ceramic coated frying pan, added two spoonfuls of the sauce in paste form, and added cold, precooked pasta. If I hadn't made it myself, I would have thought it was leftover pasta from an upscale Italian restaurant.

Can't wait to try my next recipe!!!

text:
I've cooked this recipe several times and it is amazing! The trick is to keep it on a very low heat so that the butter and cream doesn't separate. I've made the mistake of turning the heat up to speed it up but that's a definite no-go. I also use the shredded parmesan and finely chop it before adding in so it melts better. Mushroom and bacon are a great addition to this recipe as well as broccoli and chicken :) Enjoy!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have used this recipe before and again today. I didn't have any heavy cream on hand, so I used 2 cups of 2% milk and an 8 oz package of cream cheese instead. I wisked the milk into the pan with the melted butter along with two cloves of minced garlic and let these ingredients cook on med/low heat. After adding the brick of lowfat cream cheese, I let that melt down constantly wisking until the sauce finally thickened up. Served with pre-cooked Cajun seasoned chicken and angel hair pasta. Quick and easy weeknight meal. Loved it!

text:
Very good! I cut the recipe in half for just my husband and myself and I wish I had made more!I think alfredo sauce really requires a good quality Parmesan Reggiano in order to work and have a good flavor; this is what I used and it melted perfectly! I followed another reviewer's tip about whisking during the cream-butter 'simmer stage' and added the cheese a little at a time...perfect! Keep the heat low for the duration of this recipe. I like a thinner sauce myself so I added a good splash of milk at the end and whisked it to the consistency I like- no problems with separation...I also used garlic powder instead of the real thing!

So my mom came up with this great idea, we have four family members in our household and she told us each to pick a day Monday - Thursday  (we eat out on Fridays). Once we had picked our night she said "great on that night you cook dinner and do the dishes. No if, and 's, or buts about it." Me and my younger brother are sometimes picky and complain about dinner and that was her solution. In all honesty I love it! I have learned  how to cook so many different things some dishes that my mom has never even made. And tonight I made this Alfredo sauce and they all loved it, it tastes so delicious and creamy I'm definitely going to be making this again! (She also has a rule about phones it's very easy to remember, if you bring it to the table it gets taken away. Ha let's just say she runs things in our house)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an excellent base recipe. I think for full flavor, it needs quite a bit more. I doubled the recipe as leftovers are a must have in this house. I added just a sliver of butter at first and saut√©ed 1 full finely chopped shallot and added the rest of the butter then heavy cream as instructed. For a double batch, I only added one garlic clove (since I already added the shallot). I also added NO salt considering I put shallot and garlic in. In went the cheese and I added paprika, oregano and quite a bit of pepper before adding the parsley. For what it's worth, I added the curly leafed parsley and not flat leaf (it seems to chop better and personally I really think the flavor is different). I love parsley so I added a little extra as well. I don't have any for leftovers. My 16 month old kept saying "Mmmmm. More?" I gotta say there's no better validation than your kids eating all their dinner and asking for more. And honestly? Best alfredo sauce I've ever had with those additions, and of course broccoli, chicken and garlic bread!

text:
Pretty decent recipe for a basic alfredo sauce.  First time I made it, I didn't let it simmer long enough for the cheese to melt.  The next time, I added the cheese a little at a time, and kept continually stirring.  It also helped the cream to thicken up a little bit as well.  We like garlic, so I used 2 cloves (and will probably add even more next time!).  I also added some pepper to give a little bit more flavor.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I doubled this recipe and followed almost to a T, knowing that authentic alfredo is not just parm, I also used shaved asiago and romano cheeses. This sauce needs to be stirred CONStANTLY with a wisk so it does not seperate, also, I find that parm is difficult to melt, so leave it on the stove for a while after finishing on LOW mixing it while making your noodles and protein and it melts it just takes a bit. I also found this to be too thick, mixed one cup of cheese in at a time and omitted the third cup. I also added some milk because I still wasnt satisfied with the consistency....Also alfredo really NEEDS black pepper so I added a tablespoon near the end ;)

Display Name:
perrinster

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was really good and easy to make. I doubled the recipe and didn't measure exactly and it still turned out well. Most importantly it was delicious and didn't seperate. I melted one stick of butter in a pan and added four large cloves of garlic. I let the garlic soften for a few minutes. Next, I poured in one half carton of heavy cream and grateda block of parmesan cheese right into the pan. I stirred every minute or two to make sure the cheese was melting and the cream wasn't burning to the pan. The sauce will thicken once it starts to simmer. This is where you want to make sure to stir constatly. If you start making the alfredo at the same time that you start the water for the noodles the sauce should thicken enough by the time the noodles are done. So yummy! Everyone loves it.

This recipe was simple and perfect.  I used it and adjusted the recipe for 50 servings to feed my son's wrestling team.  They ate and went back for second's. The key to great sauce with dairy is slow and low.  Wisk the entire time and use the best ingredients you can afford. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wonderful alfredo recipe! I sauteed the garlic in the butter as it melted, then added the cream. I used shredded parm, and I agree with others -- there is a world of difference in flavor.

The only alterations I made were just matters of personal preference. I added black pepper, a sprinkle of nutmeg and a TBSP or so of chopped green onions at the very end.

I did end up having to thin the sauce a bit with some milk. (I probably cooked the cream too long, but that's easily corrected). Just an FYI -- this is enough sauce for about 1/2 to 2/3 lb. of pasta, depending on the pasta type and thickness of the sauce. I used linguine, and it was fantastic! Thanks for sharing!

text:
I was really excited for this after reading reviews. But, sadly, it was not that good. Maybe I did something wrong? I followed this recipe exactly as directed and after adding only half the Parmesan the safe was gritty and tasted terrible. I had to substitute milk for heavy cream, add salt and pepper and shredded mozzarella to cut the harshness of the cheese. If you like it sharp then this may be good. But I'd recommend using more mozzarella than Parmesan or maybe a milder cheese. Fresh Parmesan was too sharp and gritty for my taste. So, it's possible I did something wrong. But was very disappointed. I'll try again with some other cheese options and see.

SUPER SIMPLE AND FAT-LADEN, but oh so good! I only had 1/2c. wh. cream, so to thicken a bit I made a roux of 1 T butter and ! T flour, whisked that together (a roux makes the flour NOT lump), then proceeded with the rest of the recipe.  I used three cloves of garlic, not one, and I used 1/2 gruyere and 1/2 Parmesan. DELISH, QUICK!

I was craving something cheesy/creamy and since starting a gluten-free diet, that limits me a bit, but then I thought "Alfredo!"  As I always do, I tweaked the recipe, but used this as my guide.  I tripled the garlic, doubled the cheese, doubled the parsley, and doubled the cream...as a runner, this is not something I would normally do, but hey, indulgences are okay on occasion, right?  I think the one thing the recipe neglects to say is the let the sauce "rest" for a few minutes of the heat until it thickens.  I served with minimally peppered, baked chicken--yumm!!!!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I actually combined two recipes, but the ingredients listed here are in the recipe.  I started with one cup of chicken broth, added minced garlic, one small, thinly sliced onion, salt and pepper; let boil.  Then reduced the heat, added one cup of heavy cream, 3/4 cup of fresh grated parmesan and 1/2 cup of fresh grated pecorino romano.  I simmered on low for approx. 20 minutes, stirring constantly to prevent separating.  Added the parsley as a garnish on top of the mixed pasta and noodles.  I added a pre-cooked chicken from the grocery store to this as well.  So good.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe & super quick; I can offer a few tips I found are helpful;
don't get the butter too hot before you add the cream; start adding the cream very, very slowly at first and whisk the entire time - but this recipe only takes 5 minutes or so. I used about a half a wedge (4 oz) of Fontenella cheese cut into small chunks. The cheese is soft and very flavorful. After that I add a half cup of parmaesan cheese & the Fontenella really helps blend the parmasan. To avoid oversaltiness, I don't season until the end with pepper, parsley, garlic and marjoram. It is better to use unsalted butter but if you cut out the parmasan & only use 8 oz of fontenella, it will be just right even with salted butter. The marjoram gives a nice very subtle flavor.

None
text:
The taste of this sauce is outstanding!  My only complaint was that it seemed a bit runny to me, but that is easily fixed by either simmering the butter & cream longer or by mixing in a little flour with the butter before adding the cream, which is what I plan on doing next time.  My usual go-to recipe for alfredo has cream cheese in it, but I don't always have cream cheese on hand and this recipe is much simpler - and just as tasty, if not better!  I also add in a touch of salt and pepper and with any white sauce, I add in a little freshly grated nutmeg.  I love the simplicity of this recipe and that you can really customize it to fit your own personal taste!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Super easy to make, easy to remember! SO much better than the pre-made canned stuff. I will NEVER buy pre-made alfredo sauce again. I have found that if you don't allow the cream and butter a few minutes to simmer, the cheese does not combine well. I usually add a little black pepper and sometimes dried oregano instead of parsley if we're out of parsley.

If you have left-overs, heating goes more smoothly if you reheat in a small saucepan, stirring constantly. Refrigerated, the butter tends to separate.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
A true-to-parmesan Alfredo recipe here. The key is to use the fresh grated sort. It will render awesome bursting flavor on every noodle. I don't tend to tweek a recipe on 1st try, but I did here because I am a lover of garlic. Garlic should swim with butter for 5-minutes prior to adding the cream. Don't forget the finely cracked peppercorn on the finish, and NO salt! Fantastic simple little recipe. You will LOVE it!

text:
Yum!  Simple Alfredo sauce that can be modified to make other dishes.   Two things...the recipe does not call for salt or pepper which I believe was an oversight, but be careful....parmesan is salty in its own right so its easy to over salt.  Its also important to GRATE your parmesan or it won't melt properly.  I used shredded...pretty lumpy...my fault.

Simple and basic ingredients which can be swapped for what's on hand or fancied up if you feel like it. I used a blend of fresh grated cheddar, gyerie and parm. I loaded up with pepper and saut√©ed the garlic I'm olive oil before adding the cream and cheese. Skipped the butter since I used olive oil. text:
Quick and easy,. Don't be tempted to cut corners by using cheese that was purchased grated; it does not melt so well. At times, I have subbed half and half for the cream with good results, and have added the crushed garlic with the butter and then removed it before adding the cheese. Definitely a keeper, for a weeknight or more elaborate meal. I really love it with campanelle pasta.

text:
Simplicity. A good cook knows the basics and this is almost perfect.
One tip. I saut√© the garlic in the butter before adding the cream. Helps the garlic release it's full flavour. Add the cream and let it reach around 130f (slow of course) before you add the parm'. This will allow the sauce to fully combine the ingredients.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent, easy recipe. It's a nice lighter recipe, with some nice parmesan flavor. The changes I made:

1. I added the garlic to the butter and browned it before adding the cream and cheese - if you're not worried about how it looks, I think it adds to the flavor (the born bits might be off-putting if you have guests coming).
2. I didn't measure the cream or the cheese; I estimate I added 1.25 cups of cream and well over 1.5 cups of cheese (probably closer to 3 cups of cheese). 
3. I added a pinch of white pepper and a few shakes of salt - the salt really brought the flavors out, which is that I suspect the people who thought this recipe is bland might need to do.

I made this over egg noodles, because I didn't have any other pasta in the house, and it came out delicious!

text:
This was SO good my whole family loved it and they are not big pasta or garlic fans.
I used whole wheat fettuccine and put in some cubed leftover chicken. I also added a bit of lemon juice to the sauce which gave it a nice flavor.
I used heavy cream and 1 TB of flour which I think made it a little too thick so next time I will leave as is. My sauce came out fairly smooth and you cant even tell when its mixed in with the pasta so I wouldn't worry about that part.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I ran into the same problem someone else did where the cheese and milk (I did use milk, not cream) separated and it was lumpy and not very appealing.  I added some Italian cheese blend (about 1/4 c) and then added about a 1/3 of a stick of low-fat cream cheese and poured in a little more milk.  The cream cheese really seemed to help "smooth out" the sauce.  I also added some Wildtree Scampi blend to the milk and butter for a tasty garlic flavor. (in addition to the clove of garlic)  
Tossed it with tortellini and steamed broccoli.  It was good,  but I think I might change up the cheese next time.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this last night to go over ravioli.  It was absolutely delicious and VERY easy to make!  Used unsalted butter instead of regular butter, and I doubled the batch.  Be sure to use grated parmesan from a tub instead of a bag -- I started with grated parm out of a bag and it doesn't melt so well.  I added more from a tub (like Boars Head, you can find it in the deli case) and that melted divinely.  Upon our first bite, we could still "feel" the grated parm from the bag, so it will be tub for me from now on!  DELICIOSO!!

text:
very simple and yet very delicious. i made a few tweaking... i used 2 cups of all-purpose cream, 1/2 cup of butter and instead of using just parm cheese, i used 3/4 cup parm plus 2 tbsp cream cheese. i used 1 clove of garlic as instructed and it was enough to keep my sauce garlicky. then mix mix mix with a whisk on my pan. when all are incorporated into a thick, creamy sauce i added the japanese parsley. yum yum yum!!! my friends loved it and asked for the recipe. thank you for sharing this! :-)

text:
This sauce is so easy to make and absolutely delicious as well!  What I did was I minced the garlic first. Then I melted the butter and then sauteed the garlic in the butter.  Then I added the heavy cream and simmered for the 5 minutes, then added the cheese.  I tossed it with linguine and sauteed spinach.  SOOO DELICIOUS!!  Even my SUPER picky 11 year old LOVED it!  Will definitely be making this one again!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My boyfriend and I love this sauce! I add an extra clove of garlic and I also add a few dashes of white pepper and some fresh black pepper. We also love pesto so - depending on how pesto-y we want it - I add 1-2TB of pesto and it's super amazing! Try this with gnocchi or other pasta that will really collect the sauce.. I usually also grill or sautee some chicken with rosemary and a bit of garlic and pepper as well. Add some garlic bread and steamed broccoli and you have a fantastic Italian meal!! It's one of my boyfriend's top 2(!) meals I make, so I'd really recommend. 
P.S. As noted elsewhere, you should keep the sauce separate from the pasta if you'll need to reheat it later as the butter and cream separate and it can get a bit grainy if you don't whip it all back together. You can still microwave it, but again you'll just have to make sure it all gets smoothed back out.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I came home from work tonight knowing I'd forgotten to leave something out for dinner! The horror! I needed something quick, simple, and good enough for a picky 3 year-old daughter, and this was definitely it. Followed the recipe almost to the letter, except when I melted my butter, I added about 3/4 tsp minced garlic. I had 1 c cream I needed to use up, and this worked perfectly, though I ended up thinning out the finished sauce with 1/4 c milk. I used finely shredded parm as well as the remainder of a bag of the finely shredded Italian blend, and had no issue with it not melting. Threw in a dash of nutmeg, freshly grated black pepper, and a pinch of sea salt and voila! Used the sauce over gnocchi and sausage and threw in some steamed peas for color. Will certainly make this over and over again.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5358505.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Everytime I make this dish I enjoy it a little bit more.  We have tweaked this sauce to our liking.  I use 1/2 &1/2 instead of heavy cream.  I add 2 1/2 cups of a parmesan and parmigiano reggiano mixture.  The extra cup of chese gives more flavor and seems to thicken the suace better.  We also add 2 cloves garlic instead of one, and salt and pepper.  FRESH parsley is a must!!  It really makes the dish.  Just buy a bunch at the store and chop it up with your kitchen scissors and toss it in at the end.  Happy eating.

text:
This is a great recipe.
I've made it twice. The first time I followed the recipe and I found it to be a tad rich for my liking.
The second time, I chose to use 1 Cup of Parmesan and 1/2 cup of Gruyere to smooth it out. I also added a tad more creme. It came out pretty much to my liking. Not watery, but not thick. Being a fan of cajun seasoning, I decided to add some creole seasoning to it after I added cheese. This came out pretty good. Added sliced andouille sausage and chicken to the mix.

region:

country:
None
text:
This is a wonderful base recipe! I doubled the batch, and it reheats very well the next day if you add a little milk. (Tastes better too, the flavors have a little time to meld.) I used a microplane for the cheese and turned off the heat before mixing it in, and it came out velvety smooth.

It was a little thick even though I used light cream. I think next time I'll try half milk and half cream, more garlic and a little white wine.

text:
A very nice, basic recipe that will not fail as written.  If you chose to tweak it for your personal taste it is even better!  I used a mix of parmesan and parmigiano-reggiano plus extra garlic and it was wonderful.  We were especially pleased with the consistency.  Not to thick or too thin!  Perfect for the gluten free rice flour pasta I made to go with it.   I will make this often I'm sure because it is so much better than ready made and no more trouble.

text:
This Alfredo Sauce recipe was SLAMMIN!!!  I made sure I used the guyere cheese- best choice!  I prepared everything just as the recipe called for...While having my hubby stir the alfedo sauce to ensure it wouldn't burn, even on the lowest setting (hehehe), I sauteed a pound of medium cooked shrimp and a can of Phillips Jumbo crabmeat with some olive oil, minced garlic and a teaspoo of Phillips Crab and Shrimp seasoning.  Then I combined the sauce with the sauteed crab and shrimp and added in a half bag of cooked ronzoni wheat egg-style noodles!!! Mmmmmmm- to die for!!- Oh and I added half a bag of frozen broccoli cuts too!!

text:
this alfredo sauce was absolutely delicious, although I made a few modfications. First, I used two cloves of garlic, and I sauteed them in the butter, rather than add raw garlic to the sauce. I also grated fresh nutmeg and black pepper into the sauce. The texture was a bit grainy for my liking; I think next time I'll used a blend of parmesean and asagio and/or romano. 
All in all, I found the sauce delicious, and I'll definitely be keeping the recipe.

text:
This is a yummy and easy recipe. I adjusted the ingredients in the recipe to one and a half times to feed my family of four but next time I would just go ahead and double it. I also used half and half instead of heavy cream and I whisked it the whole time it simmered, slowly adding in the fresh Parmesan.  For my stove medium low was not hot enough and so I simmered over medium.  I used two garlic cloves this time so maybe I will use three next time I make it if I double the recipe.  I also added fresh ground pepper and a couple of dashes of nutmeg.  I served it over fresh fettuccine (Buitoni) and it was yummy :-)

text:
Amazing! Tried it as it the first time and have been tweaking it to my tastes ever since. It deserves five stars as it is, but I enjoy using a blend of 1/2 romano, 1/2 parmigiano reggiano and using a generous 1/4 cup of unsalted butter. I also cut down on the parlsey, and add a little basil and oregano. It pairs quite well with broccoli or asparagus and a nice glass of wine.

text:
I love this alfredo sauce.  I always throw a bit of pepper into in so it's not so blah looking and I never have fresh parsley on hand so the pepper adds another layer of flavor as well as a little bit to look at.  Also for the cheese, I made this with only having bags of shredded parm. and it took a lot loner to melt.  So the next time I made it, I used my can of grated parmesan cheese and it mixed right in and thickened up, now I just go off the basics of this recipe and experiment a little...  Yummy!

text:
This is a great alfredo sauce. First you must simmer this sauce, if you bring it to a boil it will separate. Second, increase the garlic to two cloves. And most important use your own fresh grated cheese. If you use the kind in the green can made for shaking on pasta, it will not melt right!    Also, I have to laugh at the ones who say, "I'm Italian and this isnt' the kind they serve in Italy". Alfredo is an AMERICAN dish, there is no Italian version. LOL There is a butter and cream sauce in Italy but it is NOT alfredo nor does it taste like a garlic, parmesan, cream sauce.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2010-09-20T19:36:49.653
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
5418540
Display Name:
Pirate girl
isPro:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
4 stars for taste!  DO NOT USE MILK, unless you want alfredo soup! Stir vigorously after each addition of parm., add it slowly, about a 1/4 cup at a time.  Try a pinch of nutmeg, most alfredo sauces call for it.  And definitely add pepper, white or black is fine!

text:
I add bacon and fresh green onions to this dish, and the family loves it! Also, you can convert this recipe into a roasted red pepper sauce or a tomato alfredo by adding a jar of roasted red peppers puree (add jar into the blender, add while you add milk) or a couple table spoon of tomato paste.  Very good, very easy!! love this recipe!

text:
This was wonderful.  However I substituted one large container of fat free Greek yogurt for the heavy cream, added more fresh garlic and little more butter and added about 1/2 cup of finely diced Portabello mushrooms to it.  I used the Kraft Parmesan cheese, but next time I'll get the fresh and grate it myself.  As smooth as it looked it was a bit grainy textured.  I also cooked it in my electric wok which worked brilliantly.  The woman whose husband almost wept would have literally wept at the taste of this stuff.  Excellent and I like the fact that I could substitute for the heavy cream -- I know it must be better tasting, but the HC has just way too much fat for me.  This was a really easy recipe to make for a dinner party and it was smashing~
