photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the basic template for Alfredo Sauce. While there are a million substitutes out there, the staples (butter, heavy cream, and parm cheese) should not be omitted. This is the kind of sauce that take multiple tries, not because it is difficult to make, but because we all like it different ways. I make my Alfredo thick and rich. I allow the cream to thicken before adding parmesan And romano cheese. Use fresh whenever available. The pre-grated kind will give you lumpy results most of the time. Also, season the finished sauce with salt and peper (white pepper, if you care about looks) to taste.

text:
I prefer a lot more seasonings in my cooking but this was a great recipe to jump off of. The cheese and cream combo was great - you just have to wisk it really well as it cooks to get a creamy consistency. I seasoned the sauce with a pinch of salt, white pepper and garlic powder. I added sauteed chicken that I seasoned with salt, pepper, garlic, basil and oregano. I also added some diced tomatoes and served it over fresh fettucini. Pretty good!

None
text:
Great and east recipe! I love making this sauce over chicken, broccoli, and ziti. 
I cut and cook the chicken and broccoli into bite size pieces, then add it to the cooked ziti and pour the alfedo sauce over eveything. Makes a great dish! The alfredo sauce sticks to the ziti pasta really well. I also add 4 cloves of garlic instead of one. And be sure to used shredded parmesan as other reviewers have suggest, It really does melt alot nicer. Be sure to add a handful of parmesan at a time as you wisk (mix) the sauce, the sauce will be alot smoother. :)

country:

text:
WOW! Very simple, very impressive! This sauce is so similar to Olive Garden's! I could not find freshly GRATED Parmesan cheese in the cheese section of HEB ( a popular grocery chain in Texas). I finally found 6 oz. tubs of Digiorno brand grated Parmesan in the Deli area. I made a double batch and it was more than enough to coat about 20 oz. of bowtie pasta. I used unsalted butter as recommended and I threw in some precooked cocktail shrimp (from the frozen seafood section) that I thawed out under running water. The sauce was brought to a gradual simmer and it began to thicken after 5 min. I was afraid to let it go longer for fear of the sauce breaking. Maybe I should have cooked it a little longer because I could feel the lil granules of cheese. Other than that, THIS ONE STAYS IN MY RECIPE BOX!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I feel kinda bad for reviewing this, because I did change it some, but I wanted other readers to see the changes.

I substituted fat free half and half (with a touch of corn starch) in place of the heavy cream...anyone notice the fat conent?  Replace with half and half and you'll be happy you did.

I also increased the garlic to about 6 cloves of very finely minced garlic.  Alfredo sauce needs more then 1 clove.

I also added about a teaspoon or so of freshly ground black pepper.  Black pepper is essential to a great alfredo sauce.

Also, I used hald parmesan and half romano cheeses, just as a preference.  Always make sure you buy a wedge and grate it yourself.  The stuff in the jar and in bags will not melt properly and you will end up with a clumpy wierd tasting sauce.

Excellent sauce. My DH is pretty picky when it comes to alfredo sauce, and I had not found one that he liked. He told me I had outdone myself with this one. I used half and half to try to lighten it a bit. I also used an italian 3 cheese blend. You have to stir and stir; it will melt!  I was concerned at first because it seemed thin. However, I pured it over the pasta and let it sit for just a couple of minutes before serving.  It was perfect! Thanks for a great sauce. We can't wait to try it on chicken.

I'm only giving it 4 because I added to this.  I used 3 cloves garlic (minced), 1/2 cup 2% milk, 2 tsp white sugar, 1 tsp oregano, and 1/4 cup Prego Fresh Mushroom sauce (in the glass jar).  It balanced out the flavor and turned it into an alfredo marinara sauce which was wonderful over cheese tortelini.

text:
I'm sorry, Rebecca

The recipe seemed to have so much promise...It seemed to have such simple, tasty ingredients...I even went whole hog and got *real* ingredients (cheese, did not skimp on the cream, etc) but it seemed to lack something.  I did some reasearch on the site and found that nutmeg is a staple in the sauce.  Being allergic to nutmeg, I used a dash of allspice and the sauce improved tenfold. It was very tasty...but the consistancy...It might have been the real parmesean, but it was elastic-y.  I don't know how to solve that problem.  My kids took one look and wouldn't try it (they have had alfredo before).  I'm sorry for the bad review, but I am going to be looking for a new recipe.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the easiest and best alfredo recipe I have ever made.  I use freshly shredded parmesan cheese instead of grated and I use approximately 2 cups instead of the 1 1/2 that the recipe calls for.  I've found that if you don't use at least 2 cups the sauce is somewhat thin rather than a thick and cheesey. I add the cheese gradually because if you add it all at once it becomes lumpy like some of the other reviews have stated.  Also, you must whisk the entire time you are adding the cheese, and do it quickly.  Trust me, this recipe is to die for.  All of my friends and family now use this for their sauce as well.

text:
This tastes really delicious, but the texture sucks. Though I have made it several times, it is always grainy. I even tried putting it in a blender once! I cannot find gruyere cheese anywhere, so I have not tried that. The recipe also lacks nutmeg - a very important alfredo ingredient, which I added. Also put a bit more garlic and seasoned it a bit. Left out the parsley, I don't care for it in alfredo. This tastes great with shrimp & pasta, but the texture kinda kills it for me... I may try with a different cheese sometime. Still, i'd like to know the resturaunt's secrets for smooth alfredo... I think I will try another recipe next time!

text:
Good flavor, but very gritty.  The sauce appeared very smooth, and did not separate, but when we tasted it we found out the parmesan cheese had not fully melted.  Next time I'll try Gruyere cheese, and also cut the amount of cheese down -- 1-1/2 cups was a bit overpowering.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is fabulous as a base for a great pasta dish. When the cheese is almost completely melted, I add chopped green onions and julienne cut sun-dried tomatoes (I've used both the ones packed in oil and just the dry ones and they both work fine). Separately, I cook diced chicken breast with white wine and garlic. Then I mix chicken and sauce together with some penne pasta and it tastes sooo good. I once tripled the recipe when I was visiting family to serve about 10 people, and they ALL loved it.

I've never had Olive Garden's sauce, but I have had Red Lobster's crab alfredo sauce (which I adore).  I added one can of lump crab meat at the end and it was a dead ringer for it.  So easy!  You won't need another alfredo recipe again!

text:
08/03/01
Chandra
This was my first attempt at alfredo sauce.  I decided to oven roast the garlic first and add both parmesan and an italian blend of cheeses.  The taste was amazing.  However, I had a hard time getting the sauce to thicken.  I just mixed some flour and water together and that did the trick.  I used the sauce in combination with a chicken and shrimp saute recipe that I got from the McCormick web site.  The recipe was called Chesapeak Bay Chicken and Shrimp with Penne Pasta.  I just replaced the cream with the alfredo sauce.  Thanks again, it was great

text:
Yes, we will make again. Here are our variations - 13oz shredded Parmesan, 24oz of heavy whipping cream, 1.5-2 tsp minced garlic (from a jar), 1 tsp salt. We did have to turn up the heat to med-high to melt the cheese.  Very tasty! Our sauce was not thick, probably due to the amount of cream we added.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is not good. I wonder if this recipe was intended for pretend parmesan (eg. the stuff you buy on the shelf by the pasta). I used real, freshly grated, aged parmesan and that's all you could taste-- don't get me wrong, I love parmesan, but that's all that the flavour was.

To try and fix it, I added more garlic, the juice from half a lemon, as well as the zest from a whole lemon, a few good pinches of pepper, extra fresh parsley, and I let it reduce for a good 30 minutes. It wasn't bad after I did all of that, but this recipe is not good if you don't tweak, and even then, it was by no means a great alfredo.

text:
So I was going to make it just like the recipe but I changed things up a bit. I used a little less than a 1/4 cup of butter, no cream just 1% milk. I added a little more than a cup of the milk, maybe like 1/4 more. I used a pre-shredded Parmesan mix that had Asiago in it and added some basil and a dash of nutmeg too. Lastly because the milk made it runny I made a roux of 1/4 cup milk and heaping tablespoon of flour which I whisked in when it was lightly boiling. My kids just loved it.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make this at least once monthly and it always turns out great. It's super easy and always a hit. I do vary the seasonings (sometimes just using black pepper and a dash of nutmeg, other times adding a little Italian seasoning, which includes marjoram, parsley and basil).

I will say this recipe can be trial-and-error, as it relates to the type of cheese used. I've had instances where it comes out too salty or too thick and the only thing I changed was the cheese. What I find works best for me is the fresh, shredded grocery store parmesan (only, not mixed with other cheeses).  I get consistent, delicious results with that kind.
Review:

1

text:
This alfredo recipe is a family favorite. I have made this several times by now and have tweaked it a bit to fit my personal cooking style and taste. One change I made was reducing the amount of butter from 1/4 a cup to 2 tbs.  And I add a tsp or two of freshly ground black pepper and a couple pinches of salt. Overall, this is an easy recipe to make and hard recipe to mess up! I highly recommend giving this one a try.

text:
I made it just as described. Actually this is my second time making it. I precook chicken breasts, shred them, and throw some cooked pieces over the top of the noodles before putting this sauce on. It's one of my fiancee and my favorite dinners. So easy and delicious, but so elegant. I substituted 1 tbsp. of minced garlic, and half & half with a tbsp of milk (because it's what I had in the house on hand), and bottled parsely flakes,  and I can't believe it's not butter. I've made it the other way also, and honestly, it's just as amazing to our tastebuds. I substitute with what I have on hand with many recipes. As long as the substitutes are close, it's certain that you won't be disappointed, either way. We loved it, substitutes or no. I highly recommend making  this recipe. It's a winner!

This is my go-to alfredo recipe. It is so easy to make. I use pre-shredded parmesan, but make sure it is the kind with no fillers (cellulose, etc), just cheese. I add it 1/2 cup at a time. I also cooked some cut up chicken and when it was almost done threw the garlic in with it to saute instead of putting it in the sauce. I think next time I'll keep it in the sauce.

I doubled the recipe and it was delicious but I would not consider this Alfredo sauce. This is a rich parm cheese cream sauce. It was perfect to top our lightly breaded pan fried chicken. It was very rich though so a little bit went a long way. An Alfredo sauce should have a smoother consistency and a more mild flavor- this tasted like pure parm cheese.

text:
Out of necessity, I did change this recipe a little... I had doubled the recipe and realized I didn't have enough parmesan cheese, so I used what we had on hand ~ garlic and chive white cheddar cheese curds (which I grated) to account for the missing parm. The flavor and consistency were amazing and it definitely kicked it up a notch.
My family loved it and from now on, I'll be making it this way every time. 
(In case you're wondering, I only had about one cup of parmesan. I grated enough cheese curds to make about 2 cups. DEFINITELY worth it!!)

text:
The key to this recipe is to use GRATED Parmesan cheese. I made the mistake, once before, using shredded cheese and that turned into a sticky mess. It was still edible, but certainly not the creamy texture that using grated cheese gives you. Overall, this is a great base to use; I enjoy it just as it‚Äôs written. It also makes a good base to add other ingredients based on your taste preferences.

Great basic recipe for Alfredo.  Can add a bit of nutmeg for a more traditional Alfredo. I add fresh parsley from my garden when it‚Äôs in season. I also like to add artichoke hearts and/or chicken breast and top it with fresh diced tomatoes. The tomatoes give it a carbonara vibe and add a light, cool and fresh quality to a sauce that is heavy. I add a a couple tablespoons more of Parmesan. Sometimes, I add Asiago with the parm. I grate them finely and they melt bueutifully.

userID:
25057574
Display Name:
Ruth Solomon Doraiswamy
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
4
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6349362.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My first time making Alfredo sauce and it was surprisingly very easy. I gave this recipe a few tweaks because I found the Parmesan cheese flavor to be a bit overwhelming:
1. I added a little salt (like maybe 1/8 tsp) and freshly ground black pepper (1/4-1/2 tsp depending on how much you like black pepper).
2. I also added 1/4tsp of ground nutmeg
3. I added a couple TBs of whole milk at the end and whisked it in to incorporate with the sauce and thin it out a touch.
4. I made the pasta separately and drained most of the pasta water except for maybe a 1/2-3/4c of pasta water. I then added 3 big handfuls of baby spinach, gave a good stir, partially covered with a lid (to let the steam escape) and set it to low for 5 min or so to let the spinach wilt - not to where it was soggy, just until softened.
5. I added the pasta and spinach to the Alfredo sauce, added a little oregano (1/4-1/2tsp), stirred again, then garnished with some chopped parsley.

In the future, I may make the following changes:
1. Maybe substitute 1/2 the Parmesan with Gruyere or another cheese , to offset the Parmesan a little bit.
2. Instead of oregano, I may add Italian seasoning when I add the nutmeg.
3. Add other veggies such as broccoli/cauliflower mix (like a Normandy frozen veggie mix)
Review:
Rating:
5

2019-03-09T23:58:18.15

text:
Super yummy recipe (with a few minor adjustments and a secret ingredient)!Here‚Äôs what I did: 1 stick of butter, 1/2 cup of minced white onion, followed by 2 cups of heavy cream, 2 16oz. bags of parmesan cheese (I had a handful of Italian mixed cheese in my fridge so I added that too). While whisking I added salt, pepper, garlic powder and the secret ingredient, nutmeg. Yes I said nutmeg!  So yummy and now my new alfredo sauce recipe keeper!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I doubled this recipe for a large dish with tortellini, chicken, and spinach.  It tasted good, but either I didn't use enough parmesan cheese (use actual parmesan, not that powdery stuff, and it'll melt for you) or there's just way too much butter in this recipe, because I wound up having a giant puddle of butter at the bottom of my container the next day.  Which don't get me wrong, it tasted good, but still.

I'd recommend halving the amount of butter you use to start with, and/or adding some milk with flour to help make it a little creamier.

Oh, and add lots of black pepper and oregano.

Display Name:
baseballmom3

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2561879.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I double it. This is an amazing recipe if you use the right Parmesan cheese. I don't usually add the Parsley and I do add pepper. So easy and so good. I cut up and cook about a pound of chicken breasts in a pan with 2-3 Tbsp of salted butter and black pepper, then transfer the chicken to a dish, then put a stick of butter and 2 tsp. of minced garlic in the pan I just cooked the chicken in, stir it until the butter melts, add 2 cups of heavy cream, stir until the cream is nice and hot, then add about 2 cups of shredded Parmesan. Once the Parm has melted and the sauce is a bit thickened, I add the chicken back in, turn it all to low, and cover and cook it all for about 10 more minutes, or until the pasta is done. A family favorite.

Then Boiled some fresh broccoli about two handfuls you can use frozen broccoli but I prefer fresh. When the broccoli and Chicken are done you just put them aside and then start making the Alfredo sauce. Put the chicken and the broccoli on a plate and just pour the Alfredo sauce all over the chicken and broccoli. Omg, delicious. And there you go a low-carb meal.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5081762.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic modern Alfedo. Considering that real Alfredo sauce is nothing more than butter & Parmesan cheese for the sauce, this wasn't bad at all. For those who don't know alfredo history, here you go! 

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fettuccine_Alfredo

I too lived in Italy for some time and have a problem with American wannabe Italian anything. Newer versions of this sauce include thickening agents & or cream. I added a bit more garlic to it to go with salt & pepper. I had unsalted butter. I used flat leaf parsley. Along with some fresh garlic, put it through my presser so it came out nice and crushed as opposed to minced jar garlic. Added a splash of white cooking wine. A pinch of nutmeg & 1 egg. & half cup of romano cheese & only 1 cup of Parmesan cheese.

I think you should try your food as you are making it at that same time, so that if you need to add something that you think would compliment it, you can do so. I enjoyed it. Thanks.
Review:

3

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Best Alfredo sauce I‚Äôve ever had! Definitely need to whisk it quickly to blend the Parm cheese and make it less gritty than it appears when it‚Äôs just stirred gently. I use a 6-serving ingredient list, but used only 1-1/4 cups parm cheese instead of the 2-1/4 cups it called for. To reheat for leftovers, I suggest you keep the sauce in a small saucepan and reheat slowly on stovetop. It will be very buttery/oily at first, so you must again strongly whisk it to get back to its creamy texture. Don‚Äôt use a microwave to reheat bc it just gets oily and gritty.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4619905.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A few tips that were omitted from the recipe. 

You want to add 1/2 tablespoon of cornstarch to the cheese prior to adding into the hot cream mixture. Coat the cheese with it. That should stop it from separating or clumping. 

 Also if it gets too thick use a bit of the pasta cooking water to loosen it up. 

Throw the hot pasta directly from the water into the sauce and finish in the pan. 

Quality of ingredients is super important here. If you are using crappy parm you will have issues. 

This worked out well for me. Flavor was good and consistency was great after the above modifications. Minus one star for the missing basics.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2017-12-05T01:44:00.787

userID:

Display Name:
Erin C.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I thought it was good and easy to make. DON'T use the "parmesan" in the green shaker container. That stuff is grainy and isn't going to melt. The best cheese to use would be actual Parmigiano-Reggiano, but it's pricey. I used the pre-shredded cheese you get in a bag, and added it a little at a time while whisking. Melt it all the way before adding the next bit of cheese. Make sure you whisk the whole time it's on the stove, or it can separate. If you want it thicker you could add a little flour.  I used extra garlic and lots of black pepper for seasoning. Overall a pretty good recipe, but might be a bit too bland for some people.

text:
Great base.. I also agree with another reviewer that it's as good as the quality of ingredients.  I tweaked a lil as follows:  I sauteed 2 cloves of garlic in the melted butter.  Added a splash of white wine and 1/4 cup of chicken broth before the cheese.  I used 1 cup of shredded Parmesan cheese, 1 cup of shredded Italian cheese mix and 1/4 cup of cream cheese.  Once the cheese was smooth I added a cup of sliced mushrooms.  Added garlic salt, pepper, Italian seasoning to taste.  Garnished with fresh parsley.  Final result was excellent!

text:
As a husband I do most of the cooking. I love it ! As for most any sauce recipe u come across... u want to throw your own personal taste and touches on. We did just that. Let me say first ... as most Alfredo pastas from restaurants r very heavy! This one is not ! It's nice and light. But again use your own personal preferences to spice or lighten up this sauce. We added extra garlic. Thought the recipe skimped on it. Extra parm which melted amazingly. Ground tyme and crushed red pepper. Extra pepper. Because that's what we like here. It came out amazing. Remember.... when u use someone else's recipe u will need to use your own touch to make it yours ! Throw your own touches on it to your own

text:
So this was my second attempt at making homemade Alfredo, the first was very unsuccessful.  This recipe was easy to follow and it was a quick process.  Apparently Julia Childs was right, its all in the butter.

The reason I like this recipe so much is because its very basic.  I like that I could add almost anything into it to get the flavor I wanted.  So I added seasonings to match the chicken that I was going to be putting in it.  I could just as easily have added lemon to make lemon pepper chicken Alfredo and I like that.

I would like to add that I did cheat and I used Kraft pre-shredded Italian cheese and it worked wonderfully.

text:
I was very short on time and needed a quick and easy alfredo for my fettuccini, so when I found this very basic one I was all over it.  Had all the basic ingredients, but had to use some Italian 4-cheese  shredded along with some grated parmessan.   I also added a small dash of nutmeg to the cheese and garlic before I added those  (nutmeg to me, has always added a little extra flavor to alfredo).  Put this right into my recipe box, in case I might forget the simplicity of it. 
 Great , simple, and basic.  We loved it!.

text:
There are really people that don't like this recipe? Wow. Two words: FRESH Parmesan, NOT the junk you buy in a container. Use the type that you buy in a block, chop it in the food processor. I use whipping cream versus the heavy cream. Pan fry some chicken with flour, paprika, a little salt and pepper. Add the chicken to the sauce and noodles. Bingo!

text:
I have made this a bunch of times, I love garlic so I add extra!  And watch the parmesean , most of it has so much ground celluose it actually does not taste at all like cheese but more like trees,, For those that said it was bland, it can be sparked up  to suit your taste buds.  it is a basic recipe that can be used using so many different meats and sea food, my favorite is shrimp and scallops,, lots of garlic and butter.. Margerine, not for me.. do your self a favor and use real butter.. you will love it. And you really do not have to use heavy cream either,  using regular Vit  D milk is good and if it needs thickening, just add a bit of flour,, no brainer.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
It's pretty good, the consistency can be difficult to achieve if not heated properly. Butter and cream need to be really hot before adding Parmesan cheese or it will not melt properly. I let the cream and butter come to a simmer and then add the Parmesan cheese and continue stirring until smooth. Best to use fresh! This is good as left overs but the sauce will harden when cooled so it is best to pour over noodles and chicken when you store it!

text:
I have made this several times and it turned out really good! I didn't use heavy cream, I used 2% milk and a teaspoon of flour to thicken the sauce. Also the parmesan cheese didn't melt very well so I would have parmesan cheese chunks I'm the sauce with is perfectly fine with me. if you want a smoother sauce I would suggest using different type of cheese as parmesan typically does not melt. overall very easy to make and this is now in my regular cooking!

text:
Parmesan melts well, but you have to remove it promptly from the stove once heated through. Leaving it on the stove for longer than needed to melt it will cause it to separate from the cream. Anyway, great recipe. I have made it 100 times at least. A family favorite.

text:
This was fantastic and so easy!  The sauce is rich and creamy, the other reviews were right when they said it tastes like an alfredo sauce you would order at a restaurant. It can take a while for the butter and heavy cream mixture to simmer, but be patient! I read some reviews that the cheese made the sauce grainy, but it melted perfectly in mine (I used bagged, shredded parmesan). I think the key is the slow simmer. It's so delicious and simple  that I already know I'll be making this again for friends and family!

text:
Very, very good. The key is to buy a block of aged Parmesan and  grate it yourself. Let it get to room temperature before trying to melt it into the sauce. Definitely want to add an extra clove or two of garlic and maybe some black pepper. Also, cook the garlic with the butter for a couple of minutes before adding the cream. All in all a very good sauce.

Super easy recipe for anyone that is making it for the first time (myself) and also if you're looking for something quick. I like food on the saltier side, but for those of you who don't, dont use salted butter! The cheese itself should add enough saltiness, if you use salted butter it will probably take it over the top.

text:
Delicious ! Double up for a pound of fettuccine.  I added a package of cubed prosciutto to the melting butter, do double the garlic. Bacon or pancetta good too.  A little flour thickens it up as necessary depending on how much and what kind of cheese you use.  I used hard grated parmigiano reggiano and some left over asiago.  When you drain your pasta, pour half of the sauce in the bottom of the pasta pot, dump in the pasta, put the rest of the sauce on top and toss with tongs.

text:
I think there might be a problem with the ratio of cheese to heavy cream as written. I scrolled through some reviews and noticed others had similar problems. I used a bag of shredded parmesan from the grocery store which is equivalent to 1.5 cups. This was way too much cheese, and it essentially turned my sauce into a stringy thick glob. I had to add at least double the amount of heavy cream in order to get it back into liquid form.

best review right herrrrrr. first review ever I mean i ever did. this is what you can do to make this recipe even better.
after melting butter saute garlic in it then add heaving shipping cream/ cream chesse/ or milk with a little starch or non. (adjust garlic to your tasting more is always better in the sense of garlic). cheeses to add this can range. I suggest mild cheddar or Sharp, asiago, parmesan and a combination of these won't hurt and makes all thr better. any veggie goes exceptionally well. (as I am vegetarian) ones to use are sliced mushrooms and tomatoes  (which are a fruit technically speaking). also the grand finales, add fresh spinach at the end., I mean the end don't cook it unless you want to, i perfer it fresh. salt and pepper add a great deal to this recipes, even making it or breaking it. thanks hope you like the review

Wonderful!! This was so easy!  Very similar to Olive Garden! I skipped the fresh parsley just bec I didn't have any, so I used a small amount of dried parsley. Key is to continue to stir it. It does thicken after about 15 min. U might thinks it's runny but it will thicken perfectly. I doubled the recipe (fed 7 with 2nd and extra) and used SHREDDED parmesan, it melted perfect. I added it slowly to ensure it melted. Everyone Love this! Quick & Simple!

I made this twice now, and love it...the first time I used shredded parmesan and the 2nd time I used gruyere that I shredded.  They were both really good, but the gruyere won!  I was so rich and flavorful.  I made the recipe exactly as stated, consistency was perfect. Will always use this for my alfredo dishes.

text:
I happen to have a horrible habit of making food when I have insomnia (works out for lunches the following day though).

I made a bit more of the sauce because it's a habit (recipes sometimes don't offer enough sauce, in my opinion).

We were low on cream so I added milk to make up for it and I don't think it made the sauce less rich. Another tip I've used for replacing cream is to use condensed milk.

Wonderful recipe! A keeper for certain!

country:

text:
I will definitely make this again.  I just happened to have some cream I thought I'd use up and this fit the bill.  It was late in the evening so I substituted dry for the fresh.  I didn't have fresh parsley so I substituted 1 TBS of dry parsley.  Instead of fresh garlic I used 1/4 TSP of garlic powder.  I only had parmesan reggiano so I used that instead of parmesan.  Other than that, it came out fantastic for a last minute throw together sauce.  I'd definitely use this recipe again but I might try milk (only because this was so rich) to see how that works.  Better tasting than any restaurant Alfredo sauce I've had.

text:
Great recipe, and I was able to cut the fat by using half and half, only 1 cup of cheese (when pared down for 4 servings) and it was more than enough. I also simmered the garlic in the butter so the flavor would infuse the butter. For personal preference, I thickened the sauce with 2 Tbs of a cornstarch milk slurry. I want to try this with Swiss cheese, instead of the Parmesan, too. Served over store-bought mushroom ravioli. Was a very romantic dinner with little effort. Keeper recipe.

First time making alfredo like this. Wish it had been mentioned that you should add the Parmesan to a butter/cream mixture that isn't too hot. It wouldn't mix, it just melted into a large ball of cheese. So I did some research, took the ball of cheese out and let it cool and added the extra cheese I had left. It blended a little better but still too loose and clumpy. Now I have to figure out what's for dinner. What a waste!

text:
After making this three times, I finally nailed it.Key is to use unsalted butter and freshly grate your own cheese.
The two times before it did come out good but was salty and lumpy from using salted butter and pre-packaged  grated cheese.The Anti caking agent they use to stop the shreds from sticking made the sauce lumpy.Will definitely  make again now that I got it right!

20405413
Display Name:
somapalma03
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
2
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3932055.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first time making sauce myself, so I was pleased with the simplicity of this recipe. My 6 year old daughter and husband loved it, and both are picky eaters. My daughter hardly ever eats anything I make, but tonight she was asking for seconds and commenting on how good it was the entire way through dinner. However, the recipe definitely required some tweaking for my taste. I love garlic, and I do not enjoy bland food at all. I cannot enjoy store bought Alfredo sauce. I feel I have tried them all, and I've never been satisfied. Instead of 1 clove of garlic, I added about 10-15 cloves plus a little bit of garlic powder. Some people may find that to be excessive, but I have grown up eating very spicy, very flavorful foods, so for my family it was just right.  I also added some salt and pepper. Like the other reviews say, the parmesan cheese does not seem to melt well. However, what I found is that once you mix it in with the fettuccine, that makes no difference. I have to say that it tastes better than it looks in the pot once you add the pasta. When I tasted it directly from the pot, I wasn't sure what I thought of it. Once I mixed the pasta in with it, I found myself making seconds. The consistency was great as well, very creamy. I recommend it, but I gave 4 stars instead of 5 because it needed to be tweaked.
Review:

text:
This recipe is so great. Looking at the reviews I decided to try it with Kraft's pre-grated parmesan in the green bottle and it was definitely way too grainy. The next day I bought fresh parmesan and grated it myself ... SO delicious and it smells great. Don't use any short cuts with Kraft's parmesan! Never buying alfredo sauce again. Tip: Don't rush when whisking the cheese in. If you whisk long enough the cheese will melt and it'll be creamy and less oozy.

Delicious. My husband and I loved it! I agree that the parmesan cheese doesn't melt smoothly. If you're making a whole box of fettuccine you'll probably want to at least double the recipe.

text:
This is my go-to  Alfredo sauce recipe. I always use Parmesan that I grate myself. I think when people complain about recipes that call for grated cheese they are using cheese from the store that is already grated and contains an additive (like wood pulp) that changes the way the recipe turns out. The recipe will only be as good as the ingredients you put in it, folks.

Display Name:
Keith
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great base for this sauce. To take it to the next level is mostly in the preparation.  Olive oil in a hot pan, chopped garlic in the hot oil, simmer until just browning and add your protein, I used chicken. Season with salt, pepper and thyme. Cook until golden, then reduce to medium low heat and add the butter.  I used a mix of Havarti and guda cheese as I only had powdered parm in the house, which is not an appropriate substitute for Alfredo. Once the cheese is melting add your cream and reduce heat a bit and let the flavors meld.

text:
I love this recipe as a good base. I actually tripled this. I used shredded Parmesan and shredded Gruyere, six cloves of garlic, salt and 1 tbsp fresh ground pepper and 4 green onions, it came out banging. I put the garlic salt and pepper and green onion and some of the parsley in with the butter and the garlic so they married together. I used 3 cups of heavy cream over low heat and added the cheese slowly, it worked beautifully.

text:
Great recipe! I doubled the recipe and as I did I made a few changes. The first change that I made was that instead of using one clove of garlic I baked a whole head of garlic and put the baked garlic into the sauce, baked garlic tends to be a little mushy so it blends right in. The second change that I made was that I used half Parmesan and half Gruyere cheese.  With these and a little bit of cornstarch to thicken this made a phenomenal sauce! We had  shrimp fettuccine Alfredo and it was delicious!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3254120.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading many of the reviews, I took their advise on a few of the changes. I used Gruyere and Parmesan 50/50. I bought it in wedges and grated it with the food processor. I heated the butter and half and half (not heavy cream) and then slowly added the grated cheeses until it was just a little looser than I wanted for the finished product. It will continue to thicken slightly as time goes on. I whisked almost continuously and had no problem with it separating later. I also used cilantro and Italian parsley 50/50. I doubled the recipe and used it the next day as a spread for garlic bread (wow, awesome). I made home made fettuccine saut√©ed shrimp in butter and served. My wife doesn't care much for Alfredo and isn't easy to give compliments, but she said it was the best pasta dish she had ever had. I was thinking the same thing but thought it was just me. Thanks for a great recipe and for all the great ideas on how to make it better.

country:
None
text:
I used real, unsalted butter.  Shredded Parmesan in a tub.  2 cloves of fresh, organic, homegrown garlic, and let them cook in the butter for a few minutes.  I used half and half, cuz that is what I had. I slowly added the parm, whisking the entire time.   It was sooo yummy. I had never made Alfredo before. I will definitely be making this again.  
PSA:  Everyone should grow their own garlic. There are hundreds of varieties, mild to spicy hot.  Very easy to grow!!  Different varieties for different climates.   You can't beat fresh juicy garlic. It is night and day to store bought.

text:
Really simple and really tasty! The key to this sauce is once the cheese is added, you must stir constantly until melted and thickened and serve immediately. You cannot warm this on the stove, nor keep cooking it once its melted,  or; it will get grainy. I added sauteed spinach and portabellos and topped with basil flakes.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3117965.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This Alfredo is amazing as a base to your sauce. If you like mushrooms and chicken you can easily put it into your sauce to get that flavor that you may think it is lacking. Just take half the butter required in the recipe and cut up some mushrooms saut√© them. Once they are cooked add the other portion of butter. Also basil is a great ingredient to add, you can do it at the end once everything is cooked. I have always thought that many of the Alfredo sauces that people make are too thick and are over the top. The consistency is amazing in this Alfredo! Make sure to season it as well. This definitely gets my stamp of approval.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3103195.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this many times and have never had a problem.  I only use parmigiano reggiano cheese, shredded with a fine microplane.  I've never had it come out gritty and it tastes great.  The real test was when i had some leftover noodles and my husband wanted another helping.  I had a jar of Classico alfredo sauce in the pantry, so he used that.  He said it was so gross compared to the fresh version.  He was fine with the jar until I started making this.
So if it's coming out gritty you may be using cheese that is shredded too big or maybe the cream isn't hot enough to melt the cheese completely.  Freshly grated by YOU is going to make a huge difference!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great base recipe to start with.  I made a few changes and it turned out fantastic!

-Melt butter in a medium saucepan over medium low heat. Add heavy whipping cream and simmer for 5 minutes. 

-Then add 1/4 cup minced garlic crushed, "QUALITY" cheese (Parmesan (Block)/Gruyere (Grated)/8 oz Philadelphia Cream Cheese), Dash of garlic sea salt,  1/4 cup parsley, 1 fresh lemon squeezed (juice) and whisk quickly, heating through.

-Simmer is the key!  (Don't boil just light simmer where bubbles gently pop on top for 10-15 minutes w/ continuous whisk)

We also added (Chicken/Broccoli/Mushrooms/Peas)

text:
First, let me start by saying that I left out parmesan because I didn't have any in my house but that never stopped me from enjoying Alfredo so I wasn't too bothered by it. It might have been why this wasn't as flavorful as it could have been though. And with that all the way, let me say that you definitely need to add salt and black pepper to this, to your personal taste but it is definitely needed. You also have to add some kind of thickening agent to this sauce or it'll be too runny: I went with flour. Finally, I added some sauted onions to this. Overall, it was a really quick and easy alfredo sauce to make when you're in a hurry and you're not too concerned about taste.

Display Name:
HundredsAnd100s

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Lovely, quick alfredo sauce. I grew up calling it insomnia noodles because it's so quick you can make it in the middle of the night and because it will (definitely) put you to sleep.

I only used a bit of butter to saute the garlic, then added the rest after the cream had heated, stirring constantly over low heat. Lowish heat is dead important, otherwise the cream can scorch or the sauce separate, and stirring constantly is a must. Freshly grated cheese is definitely worth it; it melts better, tastes better and results in a thicker sauce. Add the cheese a bit at a time, stirring to melt it entirely until adding the next bit. Reduce the sauce, and keep a bit of the pasta water on hand to add to the dish if the sauce is too thick when you add the pasta. Delicious with spinach added.
Review:
Rating:
5

I used margarine instead of butter and Homogenized milk instead of heavy cream. I added a bit more minced garlic than the recipe calls for and cut down the parsley a touch. The best part is that it doesn't get chunky if left in the pan to warm while the pasta is cooking, which is a huge issue with many of the Alfredo recipes that exist.

text:
I prepared meatballs and wanted to change up the sauce from the traditional marinara option. Knowing my significant other loves this cheesy sauce, Alfredo was a natural choice. 

This recipe was easy to make and all ingredients were in my pantry already.

Substitutions: 

*Clove or Garlic Substitute
Minced Garlic

*Heavy Cream Substitute: 3/4 cup milk (skim, low fat, regular )
1/3 cup This recipe can also be used as a dipping sauce for bread sticks, crescent rolls, and of course pasta.

text:
I think that this is a great basic recipe. Personally, I like a stronger garlic flavor. I added about 4 small cloves instead of the 1. Also I changed up the cheese. I actually don't like parmesan cheese and rarely have it in my fridge. I did have mozzarella on hand and it worked very well. Just make sure to cut it up into really small pieces so it will melt easier.  As for seasoning, I did add some freshly ground pepper and that's about it. No need for salt if you use salted butter.

text:
Good basic alfredo sauce that lets you "garlic" it up as you see fit. I used 3 garlic cloves and 1 cup of evaporated milk. I grate my own Parmesan cheese which tastes so much better than pre-grated. In order for this sauce to become smooth and not lumpy, add the cheese in small amounts whisking really well in between each addition. I also used margarine and whisked often during the 5 minute simmer time so the evaporated milk and margarine would not separate.

text:
Super quick & easy to make! Fresh Parmesan doesn't melt well, as it sticks to the pot or pan and often the utensil you're using to mix.  So, I used Parmesan out of the shaker and added the fresh stuff at the end when I tossed the pasta in the sauce.  I also put the pasta in a frying pan with a bit of olive oil and mixed in the parsley.  Then I tossed the pasta in the sauce.  Kids & hubby devoured it. :)

text:
I made this pretty much as written. I used a bag of shredded parm which was 1-1/4 cup and added 1/4 cup Romano. I saut√©ed the garlic in butter before adding the cream. I had no problem melting the cheese and it did not come out grainy at all. I kept heat on low and kept stirring until everything was melted which happened pretty quickly. I did splash in some half and half because I think it got a bit too thick. This did not coat a whole lb of fettuccini but about 12 oz.  I thought it would be too dry if I tried to coat the whole lb.  all in all a very enjoyable meal.

Simple and delicious Alfredo sauce.

text:
I made this for lunch today, and it's not bad. I wanted pasta and I didn't have any sauce, or the time to make tomato sauce, so I was looking for something quick and easy. 

I halved the recipe since it was just for me. I didn't have heavy cream so I substituted half-n-half, as others have done. It was still very creamy - I added a little of the pasta water to thin it out. 

I do think it needs more garlic - and I added the garlic to the melted butter so it could saut√© a bit before adding the cream. (Does the recipe really want you to add raw garlic to a sauce?) I think pepper would be a good idea, as well.

text:
This recipe was very delicious, i did however, have to substitute the fresh garlic clove and parsley with dried garlic and parsley, I made sure that I made the dried garlic and parsley equivalent to fresh garlic and parsley, I also used milk instead of cream, but the thickness was perfect as it should be. My only problem, which it might have been suppose to taste this way, was that there was way to much Parmesan cheese, if you do not want an over powering taste of Parmesan cheese then i would suggest to you that you do one cup less that what it called for, I had 16 servings because I have a big family so it called for 6 cups of Parmesan Cheese, I should have done 5 cups. If it doesn't taste good enough then slowly add more Parmesan to recipe. Otherwise this is a very tasty Recipe :D

text:
Delicious start to alfredo!  DON'T BOTHER with grated parmesan - buy a wedge and do it yourself, or set the kids grating while you prep accompaniments.  I make this with about 1/2 cup less parmesan and add a little romano, as the parmesan got too overpowering.  Add some cayenne, black pepper, basil, and fold with red bell pepper, mushroom, chicken/rabbit/shrimp, and onion, and it's quite a nice meal!

Great recipe.  When stirring, I've found that an easy stirring produces a smoother sauce.  I also add 1/2 tsp of anise seed to the sauce, along with extra garlic and fresh ground black pepper.  This is a pretty basic sauce, so I wouldn't be afraid to experiment with different cheeses, spices (lightly done!) or other things. Just be creative, and enjoy cooking.

text:
I used 3 cloves of garlic, 1 1/2 cup of Gruyere and 1 cup of Parmesan cheese and another extra 3/4 cup of half and half ( didn't use heavy cream) because otherwise the sauce barely enough to toss a box of cooked noodles. ( we prefer more of a saucy Alfredo).
I also tossed in blanched broccoli florets in with the noodles and sauce, sprinkled with fresh cracked black pepper and chopped fresh parsley.
Really good !

text:
Yummmmy!  I tweaked the ingredients, because I didn't think the original recipe would cover a pound of fettuccini, I used 1 stick of butter,  3 cups of heavy cream, 8 cloves of garlic (we LOVE garlic) and only added 1 additional cup of Parmesan and the consistency was perfect!  I used the regular store bought Parmesan cheese this time, but next time I might use  fresh Parmesan and maybe some Romano or gruyere, but it's probably not necessary. It was a great, cheap and filling meal that we all loved. Delish!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this today for friends and it was heavenly! It was creamy, incredibly flavorful, and so delicious! I did use good quality Parmesan mixed with Premesano Reggiano, both of which I grated myself. It took longer than the recipe said, but it still wasn't too time consuming, and it was definitely worth it! I would suggest that you add the cheese in very little at a time, and whisk constantly!! And if it seems a bit too runny at first, don't worry, it does thicken as it sits. Everyone loved this sauce, and I was told it was better than Olive Garden's Alfredo. This is a great recipe and I will be making it regularly!

I actually managed to make this with %2 milk. All you have to do is halve the butter. prepare one half as the recipe calls and melt the other half with equal part flour to make a nice roux to mix in when the sauce is finished cooking. Thickens it right up!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/777337.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was extremely easy and came out tasting exactly what I was expecting.  I used 5oz of shredded Parmesan cheese from the fancy cheese isle in the store and I found that it melted quite easily.  You just have to stand through it til the end, and whisk until it becomes all cream. Be sure to wear your apron though!  And I strongly urge you to wash your whisk immediately when you are finished, otherwise it will be very difficult to wash once everything dries.  I do not understand the "bland" claims that came from some reviewers.  This is how Alfredo sauce tastes!

text:
My husband is a huge fan of Olive Garden's alfredo sauce.  This recipe is really close and I've made it many times.  I use half and half instead of cream and add some regular powdered parmesian to thicken it up.  I also double the garlic and throw it in with the melting butter.  To save time, I use freeze-dried parsley.  I double the recipe for extra sauce to spoon over chicken and broccoli.  So nummy!

text:
It was great.  I read some of the reviews and tweaked it as well.  Plus I added shrimp and crab meat.  Used the unsalted butter whisked from start to finish.   Instead of 1 cup of heavy cream I made a seafood broth from the shells of shrimp and crab boiled with peppercorn, garlic, salt, pepper then put through a fine strainer.  Used 1/2 cup of broth to 3/4 cup heavy cream.  Used 1cup Parmesan and 1/2 cup of asiago cheese. 2 gloves of garlic Added sun dried tomatoes finely chopped at the end with chives instead of parsley.  Pinch of red pepper flakes.  I then used the rest of the seafood broth for the pasta water.

text:
Perfect just the way it is except i left out the parsley and added a dash of white pepper and doubled the recipe but really it needs no changes. I used real unsalted butter (salted will make it too salty) and heavy cream because whats the point if you don't use the good stuff? My picky kids even loved it and thats unheard of. I added chicken and broccoli as well. If you use the right parmesan cheese it melts perfectly. I shredded a block of fresh parm and it melted like a dream. Don't use anything in a package or canister get the good stuff and shred it yourself its worth it. Fabulous!!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1202924.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fresh Parm is best. Once the cream and butter are heated put the cheese in and stir. Do NOT let it cook long, it will become very lumpy. 1-2 min max and it will be completely creamy. Any longer and it will clump.

Add one clove of chopped garlic with the butter and allow it to color slightly. You will get no flavor if you put it in with the cheese. Just chunks of garlic shock.

text:
So I deviated a bit from the recipe, but as is, the sauce is still delicious! I doubled it and added a cup of Romano cheese, grated, and an additional half cup of parm. I used heavy whipping cream because I was out of heavy cream. Other than that I combined ingredients as directed. I made this for Mother's day and my family raved about the sauce! I served it over penne pasta with spinach, turkey bacon, and mushrooms. IT IS ALL ABOUT INGREDIENTS! YOU MUST USE FRESHLY GRATED CHEESE.

country:
None
text:
This is my "go to" Alfredo recipe that makes me feel like a gourmet chef!  I've made it about 8 times in the last 3 months.  Usually, I make it exact to the recipe, but I made a small change this time.  Some of the reviews mentioned blending a bit of gruyere with the Parmesan.   I had some left over from a previous recipe so I tried it and it greatly sharpened the flavor.  My husband loved it, and so did my teen kids. I actually preferred the sauce without it and won't add it again.  Besides gruyere is expensive so I wouldn't try it unless you had it on hand.   This recipe is the best.  Try it and you'll want love it,

It's definitely a solid base recipe.  But I had to add extra milk, and it definitely needs more spices (we added salt and pepper).  I'm not totally sure whether or not the salt was necessary: my boyfriend said it needed it and I foolishly believed him without tasting it for myself first. My suggestion is to taste it while you are cooking and add more pepper/salt/other spices if it tastes bland.

Display Name:
icountbeans
isPro:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/691906.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So, like it or not, this is American Alfredo.  Nothing but butter, cream and cheese. Great recipe.  Originally Alfredo was only cheese and butter tossed on pasta.  The "Alfredo" adaption of pasta with cheese and butter was only to increase the butter.  Americans add cream, from what I read, to compensate for lesser quality cheese.  But this is definitely it.
Would love to see the instructions adapted to include more specific direction on how to temper the sauce so it doesn't break.  I see so many comments on here about broken sauces, which is a temperature issue, not a recipe issue. A low heat and steady whisking (not stirring) will keep the sauce smooth and intact. Dont let it boil, all ingredients at room temp, and grate your own cheese.  Pre-shredded has anti-caking ingredients in it.
Even so, there's not much in Alfredo, so throw what you will into the sauce before serving.  It can take it... Its a great base. I increased the garlic and added black pepper when serving.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2013-07-28T21:25:59.82
helpfulCount:

Quick, easy, delicious! I didn't have any parsley and I added a little black pepper because that's how hubby and I like our alfredo. Even before I added the pepper, though, the sauce was delicious! Served over fettuccine noodles with grilled chicken and steamed broccoli. Delish!

I thought this was great. I had used a Classico alfredo sauce the night before, but didn't have enough sauce for all the left over pasta. So I tried this recipe and it was WAY better than the Classico! I was really surprised at how much flavor there was for not having much seasoning in it. I think the parmesan cheese is what adds a lot of the great flavor. Definitely use a whisk to mix in the cheese and get it to melt in.

Very good, and my family loved it.  However, I had to add almost twice as much cream than the recipe called for.  I used a blend of shredded parmesan, asiago, and romano cheeses, and found the parmesan and asiago flavors to be overwhelming.  Next time I will try different cheeses.  But getting my son to try new foods is tough, and he loved this.  Getting my husband to eat leftovers is next to impossible, but he reheated this for lunch today and loved it again.  So I'm keeping this one.

text:
This has become my go-to recipe for alfredo sauce. I add an extra clove or two of garlic and it tastes very similar to Olive Garden's sauce.

Some people have mentioned having problems getting the parmesan to melt. I always shred my own parmesan, the shredded stuff from the store has an anti-clump coating on it that keeps the cheese from melting correctly.

A quick and easy recipe, When I used to be a prep cook at a place that we made all the noodles and sauce I can tell a difference between the good stuff and the bad and this isn't bad if you do it right. text:
I used half and half instead of heavy cream, because that was all I had on hand.  Also, I used pre-packaged minced garlic instead of crushing a fresh glove.  Also, I used a gruyere/parmesan combination.  I ended up adding a little cornstarch to the sauce to thicken it, because the lower fat cream choice was not thick enough.  If I make again I will use true heavy cream instead.  I chose this recipe because I was trying to use up gruyere.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I scaled the recipe to 4 servings.  I used real butter, heavy cream, and fresh grated parmiagiano reggiano.  The only things I did differently than the recipe stated was to omit the parsley (didn't have any), sauteed the garlic in the butter as it was melting, and stirred continuously.  The sauce never separated.  We served it over fettuccine, roasted broccoli, mushrooms, and chicken.  Due to the high fat and calorie content it's definitely not going to be a frequent indulgence, but it was delicious!  Simple, tasty, and quick!!

text:
LOVE, LOVE, LOVE!  I don't know how someone said this was bland!?!  We live in Paraguay and Alfredo is almost unheard of here.  I did (out of necessity and out of preference) make some substitutions.  I have not been able to find fresh parmesan here so I used 1/2 the amount (3/4 cup) shelf-stable Kraft parmesan.  The other ingredients were easy to find here.  I also threw in a bunch of fresh diced tomatoes when I put the cream in.  The tomatoes almost tasted sun-dried this way.  Delicious!  My friend keeps asking when I am making this again.  I won't ever go back to store bought (or those good McKormick packets even)again.  This is just too good!

text:
I followed this recipe base except I made my own adjustments to my liking. I used 1 cup of parm cheese, 1/2 cup of romano, 1/4 cup of unsalted butter, 1 clove of garlic chopped & browned with a teaspoon of olive oil, and 8 ounces of heavy cream.

Outcome: sauce was a little salty at first. Will use fresh grated parm next time. Sauce thickened alot. This can be fixed by thinning with milk. Used 1 clove and I liked it. Was not too garlic-e. 1/4 cup of butter was perfect for this sauce, had a nice color. Will add parsley next time.

Over all I liked this recipe, thanks

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried this recipe, but did not have heavy cream.

I used whole milk but the butter and milk did not thicken.  So, I added some milk and flour and used romano and asiago cheeses.  

It did thicken after adding the milk/flour mix, but still looked funny.  I should have mixed the flour with the butter as it was heating, then added the milk and I think it would have been creamier.

Otherwise, it worked out well and was very tasty.  Oh, I neglected to put parsley in it.

I used it with the Italian Saucy Chicken Parmesan recipe which is very good  which is a great recipe, except I substituted rice for the Spaghetti.  See my comment on that recipe.

text:
This is a simple and excellent recipe.  Keep it around if you need something fast a delicious when people show up unexpectedly, or anytime.  I tried substituting low fat and skim milk (separate times) for cream, and margarine for butter.  Although they were OK (the sauce tended to clump more with the substitutes), and probably had fewer calories, the full recipe is much better in flavor and texture.

country:
None
text:
Wow, could this be any easier? I won't buy jarred sauce again!  I used half-and-half because that's what I had in the fridge, added dashes of garlic powder (not garlic salt) in hopes of getting a smoother sauce, a pinch of nutmeg and some freshly ground black pepper.  I agree with the other posters that the butter used should be unsalted because Parm. is salty enough, but it was still delish!  Because my shredded Parm. didn't melt down smoothly, I decided to tell my family this was a "rustic" Alfredo sauce, LOL!  But it still tasted amazing, especially over the mushroom ravioli I served it with.

text:
The BEST alfredo sauce I have found yet. This is a keeper for sure! I will never buy jar sauce again. I used this sauce for chicken and broccoli pizza(white). Now that I've found this, I will be using this recipe for all of my alfredo meals. The only thing that I did change was that I added maybe a half cup of freshly grated Asiago cheese and a cup of shredded parmesan and added that in small portions to the sauce. I thought it was too thin and that was the reason I added a little more than what the recipe called for. The taste was so yummy and the consistency was absolutely perfect! The timer just went off so my hubby and I can finally test this pizza out. Thanks so much for sharing your recipe :)

Yummy!  I made this last night for the family, and it was a big hit!  My husband went back for seconds, and my daughter finished her plate (both are a rarity). I think it's because I used shredded cheese from the deli instead of grated (it's what I had on hand).

text:
I thought this was a wonderful base sauce. I saute some portabella mushrooms and zuchinni in butter and set aside. Then I cooked shrimp with a little olive oil and old bay seasoning and set aside also. I made the alfredo sauce exactly as the recipe states and then combined all ingredients together. I served over angel hair pasta. I like this pasta better bc it really holds onto the sauce. Make sure you whisk the sauce for the whole 5 min so it doesn't seperate. This is a keeper!

text:
My hubby and I were craving fett. alfredo late last night.  We were just about to order from a local Italian place down the street when I realized that I have all the ingredients to make myself.  It was really good.  I used 1/2 and 1/2 instead of cream because that is what I had and it is better for you. I also used fresh ramano cheese.  I stired the whole time with a fork to make sure the cheese melted and did not come out grainy.  The texture was PERFECT!  I served with fett. noodles and garlic cheese bread to sop up the sauce...YUMMY!  I would suggest to serve right away cus it gets really thick and would need more cream/milk in order for it to become thin enough to serve.  I will for sure make this again on those nights I can't figure out what to cook

Started by sautaying the garlic. I then made a buchmel by adding some flower to the melted butter & so that it'd be thicker because I only had 2% milk. I then added about 2 cups milk and did the rest of the rescipe. It was delicious, but don't make too thick of a buchmel (I did the first time) or you'll just have to thin it down even more and end up with WAY too much sauce. Not that that's a horrible thing...  Anyway- great! Delicious.

text:
This was amazing! I didn't have any fresh parm on me, so I used an Italian six cheese blend, which worked out pretty well. When I first added the cheese I was worried that it would be too much like a stringy ball of cheese so I added a bit of half and half (I'd used up all of the heavy cream), and it smoothed out nicely. : ) I also added salf and pepper and a bit of garlic powder, because it had a weird aftertaste (though I blame the cheese for that). Afterward, it tasted perfect. Great recipe. : )

None
text:
This is a great base to start from.  Thanks for the post.   Personally I wanted more of a garlic flavor.  So next time I'll dice the the crushed garlic and then lightly pan fry it while the butter is melting.  This way the oils from the garlic start to come out sooner and can infuse into the cream while it is simmering.   Also I found that dried parsley is fine, but of course doesn't have as big of a punch as fresh parsley.

Display Name:
natesmommy06

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is the best! I only make it 1-2 times/month because of the fat content, but my family loves it. I give them a choice of either homemade mac and cheese, or homemade alfredo. They choose the alfredo every time! I usually double the recipe and use a pound of shell pasta, it's easier for the kiddos to eat. I use the shredded parmesan that comes in the bags...the recipe says 1 1/2 cups and the bag is only 1 1/4 cups...but it always works out. I use a wire whisk and it usually takes about 5 minutes or so to melt all the way. It is a very quick sauce. Just make sure your water for the pasta is boiling before you start the sauce...otherwise you will be "tasting" the sauce by the spoonfuls while you are waiting for the pasta to cook! :)

text:
WOW! I have tried alot of different Alfredo recipes, but this is the BEST ever! I did what someone else recommended...used Asiago cheese. So it end up 2/3 grated cheese & 1/3 Asiago Cheese (a perfect blend).  Also my family loves garlic, so I added an extra clove.  I poured it over Fettuccini noodles (of course the longer it sits, the thicker it becomes). We had leftovers. So the next day, I made more sauce and took it to work. Each person poured it over there own portion of noodles, which made it even creamier. All anyone could say was "It's the bomb!" Needless to say, I have copied this recipe for everyone in the office.  Thanks Rebecca Swift for your submission!

text:
I cut this recipe down to one serving for myself and it was delicious! The main reason I tried this recipe was because of the fresh garlic listed. I preferred the taste of this sauce 100% more than the ones using garlic powder. I also upped the garlic a bit. I ran short on Parmesan cheese so I added in shredded Cheddar cheese to make up the rest. It was basically 2 parts Parmesan, 1 part Cheddar. It was wonderfully cheesy with the tang from the Parmesan. This is my new "go-to" Alfredo Sauce. Thanks so much for sharing your recipe!

It was awesome! However whn i cook, i consider health n carlorie. Therefore i made low-fat version f alfredo sauce instead f using heavy cream. I used the mixture f 1/2 c 1/2&1/2 n1/2 c skim milk. To thicken the sauce, i added 2-3TBL flour n whisked with the butter melted since i knw tht the mixture wouldnt b as thick as the cream. Try2 make the sauce with it coz it would b guitiless n better4 u!! I also added a pinch of nutmeg n used gruyere cheese. WONDERFUL!!!!! Hope u enjoy this sauce without guilt.

text:
This was my first attempt at making Alfredo Sauce and it turned out great! I loved the simplicity and taste.  I did make just a few changes. I used evaporated milk instead of heavy whipping cream and I tripled the garlic. I love garlic, but was surprised my family couldn't taste the garlic. I didn't have fresh parsley on hand so I used dry parsley. I added my shredded parmesan cheese to the sauce bit by bit as it melted, to prevent clumping. I also added saut√©ed chopped mushrooms to the sauce. I poured this over farfalle pasta, and cooked broccoli florets, asparagus tips, carrots and chicken. It was very tasty and my family still got their veggies. My family gives this a 4.5!

This recipe was a great start! My husband and I didn't really care for the taste of the Parmesan cheese so we replaced it with Gruyere cheese sometimes adding a bit of mozzerella. Gives it a bit more "nutty flavor."

text:
For a lower calorie/fat option, I used 2% milk instead of cream, and only a third of the required Parmesan cheese.  I used salted margarine, and when I tasted it after adding a third of the cheese, it seemed done.  Very delicious.  I've had problems getting the cheese to melt smoothly, but this alfredo sauce came out  silky.  Five stars because it was easy to modify and get a great result.

my husband and i both loved the flavor, made a few modifications: it got really thick after whisking in the parmesan so i added about 1/2 c more cream (i may not have been using the right stuff though; i couldn't find "heavy cream" so i used "whipping cream"); also, i didn't have fresh Parmesan this time, but the other reviewers are 100% correct - only use fresh...the KRAFT types leave the finished sauce very grainy. very easy, very worth it - never buying the kind in a jar again!

text:
The main reason I wanted to make fresh alfredo sauce is because the jarred versions in the store always have an odd/tangy taste to them that I can't describe.  I wanted to see if I could make some fresh alfredo from scratch. 
This recipe turned out pretty good.  I found that with all the parmesan the alfredo was a little bit on the salty side.  Also, if left sitting for too long after you pour it over the noodles it sort of separates, hardens a little.  Not sure how to alleviate that issue.  I did not have any parsley so I just tossed some basil with it.  I would make this again but need to figure out how to get rid of the over saltiness taste.

text:
While I'm not a fan of Alfredo sauce (which is strange because I love all the individual ingredients that go into it), I made this for a dinner party and everyone loved it. I changed it up a bit, adding 1 1/2 cup of parmesan and 1 1/2 cup of fontina brought to room temp. Left out the parsley and had no fresh garlic so I used garlic powder. According to my guests they would eat it again!

This recipe was okay, but I had to add alot of extra flavor to get it to taste the way my family likes. I added extra garlic, parsley, butter pepper & some corn starch to thicken it a bit. The end result was really good, but I don't think I will make this recipe again w/o the added ingredients.

text:
Great Recipe. It was a little difficult to get the parmesan to melt, but I found that if you keep whisking and adding milk over medium heat, the cheese will melt pretty evenly and the sauce will become a lot smoother in consistency. Near the end, try adding some mushrooms, cooked shrimp and some italian seasoning along with the parsley. Makes an incredible dinner!
